Though I work from home, at some point if I need to go on a run or leave for an hour or two, I am still able to access the camera and speak to her if she’s barking at the front door. For now, Facebook Portal does not have this feature. With the Echo Show there is also no need for an external hub for most of my smart devices because it’s built right in. I’m unsure if Portal has this. With the Show, there is also direct access to the internet. Just ask Alexa to play movie trailers, Prime videos, etc. The display is nice, but I would chalk up the video calling and ‘Drop in’ quality to better than that of my security cameras (also high quality).

The Facebook Portal+ display and AI camera technology far exceeds that of any other device I’ve used. I purchased this for the calling feature - which is its’ primary function. During a call, you no longer need to employ being your own camera man during the call - it’s completely hands-free and smoothly follows you around the room like a movie director. I was impressed by the range at which it accurately followed me and will even follow in the direction of your voice if you happen to step out of the frame. Very limited on other functions though and I expect more are soon to follow within the year once the ‘data breach’ blah blah stuff calms down a bit. Though the Portal does not support the PA & ‘Drop in’ functions that the Echo Show has, I can still control all of my smart home devices & groups with ease and employ all of my routines with no problem.

If you’re looking for all-around functionality and more features the Echo Show (2nd) is the way to go. If quality video calling is the priority, then you can’t beat the Portal+ for now - it far exceeds everything else in that arena.

reviews.reviewTitle: Completely Incompetent for Anything But The Most Basic Inquiries
reviews.reviewText:
The Amazon Echo has not improved at all in voice recognition since the first generation. It's this bipolar extreme between good voice recognition and absolute horrific make you want to smash your head into a brick wall frustration.

The Echo Show for what it is supposed to be able to do is incredibly inadequate and this is something that I feel should be obvious. This is 2019. Not 1995. We live in a world where even crappy cell phones can go back to apps that were opened

ANYTHING that you're doing, is completely interrupted when you ask it something else, and then afterwards, there's absolutely NO WAY to get back to what you were doing without it starting over as if it totally quit the program AFTER you asked it to switch back to it.

For instance, there's a built in web browser (Just so you don't think this is skill-related and maybe Amazon pass the buck). Let's say I'm browsing a page.. Could be anything like. Any page. I then say "What's the weather like?" It takes me away from the page to show me the weather and say it also of course. At the end if I say "resume firefox" or whatever it literally will go to the OPENING of the browser as if I had NOTHING open.

Same with the Twitch skill. So I will say "open <streamer>" and it will open the stream. Cool. then I wanted to know the weather. Cool got the weather. But now Twitch isn't being shown, so I say "resume Twitch" ... it goes to the purple Twitch home screen "X channels you follow are online. Would you like to see them?" no. when I say resume Twitch I want you to !@&*(&#^&*^ resume what was playing before I asked what the weather was.

This is so basic functionality it's not even funny.

To continue the story, I then proceed to say "Ask twitch for <streamer>" TWENTY TIMES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! To which EVERY TIME Alexa says "I dont' recognize that streamer name" then other times it opens up Wikipedia to something completely unrelated that I DID NOT SAY. So I end up resorting to asking it to open Twitch and then tapping the options on screen as if I'm using a Tablet, completely defeating the purpose of a FREAKING VOICE ASSISTANT.

Now a more simpler thing. With Google Home you can say "Turn on the energize" and it knows it's in whatever room it's in so it will turn on the lights with that scene in that room. Or you can say "Turn on the energize everywhere" and it will turn that scene on in every room in the house. OR you can say "Turn on the energize in the dining room" while in the bedroom.

Alexa? Not a chance. I mean yes. You set up rooms. Yes. You put Alexa in a certain room. No. She doesn't seem to know what room she's in nor can she turn on ANYTHING in that room without you being AS FULLY EXPLICIT.. "Turn on the energize in the bedroom" .. even though you're in the bedroom, because saying "Turn on the energize" is met with "There are multiple devices with that name, can you tell me which one you want?" then it's like defusing a bomb, because saying the natural response to that question "<name of device>" is met with "I'm sorry. I didn't understand that."

Basically you have to GIVE IT THE FULL COMMAND as if it has absolutely ZERO understanding of language or anything else. In other words it's primitive as a straw hut in the middle of the jungle.

Amazing idea, implemented boneheadedly awful. And sad to say this is why other devices are running circles around it. For all the features that Echo Show is supposed to have, it is ruined by it's complete incompetence at voice control.

And once you realize that you cannot even REMOTELY talk to it like you'd talk to something that even TRIES to mimick human conversation, it still won't understand you half the time, as evidence by me telling it to go to the streamer that I just said once and it understood and then it fails to understand twelve times and I have to actually just press buttons to get there because the voice command is garbage.

I pre-ordered the first Amazon Echo and still have it. The voice command has not improved AT ALL since then. Having a continue mode where it listens again for a follow up command is NOT better speech recognition. It's just code.

You need better AI, by like a billion lightyears of a long shot. If it didn't perform the basic functions of controlling the lights etc. with learnable , though less convenient commands, I would return it.

I don't even want to install additional skills on it because my experience using it to watch Twitch has probably taken ten years off my life. I'll just use the computer the old fashioned way because IT WORKS.

I got this so I could monitor my father at his home. First issue, without a smartphone, he couldn't set it up. In fact you have to have a cell number to link the account to. Okay, did that but I have had so many issues getting it to connect. For some reason, I always have to repeat his name; adding contacts is convoluted: adding a neighbor -- we set up the Alexa app on the neighbor's telephone and I confirmed it is working from there. Can't add the neighbor as a drop-in allowed contact.

This product is too difficult to set up and use. I have been with support multiple times. Perhaps I have too many Amazon devices and it gets confused but use case is simply an Amazon Fire Tablet with Echo Show base and this Echo Show and I can't connect with any consistency. Good idea but needs to be simplified to work and set up. One should be able to set it up on EITHER phone or PC web page. There needs to be consistency between alexa.amazon.com and the app as far as contacts are concerned or it needs to propagate immediately. Users shouldn't have to have to install alexa app to use the device. Or if they do, then at least make it easy without needing double identification setting up the app. This device is just too confusing for the average person to set up (and I would consider myself especially tech savvy).

reviews.reviewTitle: The user account situation is completely broken
reviews.reviewText:
tl;dr -- If you're buying this just for yourself to use, will probably work well. If you're trying to make it work for someone else in your Household, it's a nightmare.

I bought the new Echo Show for my daughter (who lives with her mom) so that we could video call. We had previously made M an Amazon Teen account (CID-Teen), which gave her access to watch Prime video content, and shop as an Amazon prime member. I am also a Prime Music Unlimited subscriber. Amazon Music won't let her use her Teen account play music, so we had to create a new account just for that purpose (CID-Music).

The Alexa app would not let her Sign-In with her Teen Account. Then we tried removing her from the household (CID-Teen->CID-Normal). She could then Sign-In to the Alexa app, but lost the ability to play videos, music, or shop as a prime member.

Then we tried to Sign-In with my account (CID-Parent), and add her as a comms profile (CID-Comms). This initially failed because the mobile login claim (phone number) was associated with another CID. We called support to get the number free'd up. Once we were able to create the comms profile and Sign-In, we realized that this isn't a real solution either, as she now has all of the devices for my home (lights, tv's, etc) in her Alexa companion app, as opposed to just the Echo Show device that I bought for her.

4 calls to support, ~90 minutes wasted talking to CSAs. No real solution available. Ugh.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hey Get a new echo and watch it stay on the ECHO screen
reviews.reviewText: Got a brick. Now I am waiting 2 days for a new one. If you get one and it is like this....don't go through support. Just return and replace.

It is definitely a great improvement over the last echo show in regards to larger screen and the sound, which is amazing. I am actually amazed by how good it sounds.
With that said, the really annoying banners are a distraction, moreover actually annoying. There is no way (That I’ve been able to see) to disable them. Even though I have my own pictures on the background those annoying propaganda banner keep coming up taking away from it. I purchased the product to use as I please, not rent it or leasing it to subject to see the display of things I didn’t ask for. I paid for the product and I pay for my subscription to Amazon prime and I should be able as the owner to choose what it’s displayed on the screen at all times.
Other than that it is a great device to control your home automation and to play music

It is nice product for what we wanted to use it for. It works like a kitchen TV at our house with our Hulu subscription. Only complaint is that the volume level is different by application. For example, Hulu sound may be just fine. Ask it to play music and it is really loud even though you have not adjusted the volume. Hopefully they fix this in a software update. Otherwise screen is good. I have it integrated with our home automation so it is nice to be able to tell Alexa to turn off the basement lights etc.

I have had multiple Echo devices, including the first generation Show. This is definitely an improvement on that, bigger screen, better music and sound, and video. However, more than any other single function, we use it as a digital picture frame. The background picture, when the device isn't being used for something else, can be set to an album that you have created on Amazon Photos. We loaded 400 or so photos, and they change at about one minute, which I think is a perfect time.

There are a couple of problems, though. First, the units have a tendency to stop and stay at one picture, until the unit is unplugged and plugged in again. This has been mentioned time and time again in reviews, but the Amazon team on this project has apparently either not prioritize it, or can't fix it. Expect this to continue until they make it a priority.

The second issue with this as a digital picture frame is that there's no customization, other than selecting the album. Pictures rotate chronologically, either by date taken or date uploaded. You cannot shuffle or randomize. So if you took a bunch of photos at a birthday party or wedding, you are going to see all of those pictures in succession, before it moves on to another. It's gotten to the point where I can predict what the next pictures going to be.

Also in the category of lack of customization – there is no effects that you can use with these pictures. There is no transition choice – fade,, wipe, side – nor were there any effects that can be used (Ken Burns, etc.) Amazon doesn't give you any kind of slideshow maker, and it doesn't support any third-party apps.

In the general category of Alexa – the skills have now become like Apple's app store. You can't find anything useful unless you read something about it somewhere. It suggests skills, based on one's you have already enabled. We tried that once. "Big sky" is a weather app that's pretty good. Around Christmas time, it was suggested that if we like that, we would like something called "Sky Weather". So I enabled it by voice. And then opened it. It went on for about two minutes. And Alexa did not appear to hear me calling for it to stop, so I had to scream. No more suggestions.

My home isn't smart enabled, so I'm not going to comment on its usefulness on that front. The recipes are definitely helpful, but I don't think I'll be watching much video on it. Simply finding your Amazon purchases can take time, and there's only a limited number of them that show. Finally, the "drop in". Nice idea, but these are usually going to be sitting on kitchen counters or side tables. You're going to have to squat down. In an age where everybody has an iPhone or iPad and Facetime is available, it's an inferior redundancy. (Oh, and it can be really annoying. I gave these to 2 sisters and a niece at Christmas. One of the sisters sent me a message. Suddenly, the Echo Dot next to my head started glowing and fading, glowing and fading. I couldn't figure out what the hell it was. So I could sleep, I just unplugged it. Next day, I saw other Dots glowing and fading, and went into the Show to find out what the heck was going on. Apparently it was the message, and it doesn't stop until you read it. Thanks, but I think I'll stick to texting.

They still haven't found the homerun app for this device. For us right now, it's pretty much a $229 picture frame that doesn't do everything we would like it to do.

I bought one of these and was excited at how big and bright the screen is. I got it all customized to my liking. Then when I went to listen to music, there was no sound. I factory reset it and tried again. No sound, even in the introductory video. Contacted Amazon support and they decided it was defective and sent a replacement.

Second unit arrived. No sound. Called support to try and return it. I was connected to tech support who this time had me unplug the power cord from the back of the Echo Show and leave it unplugged for two minutes. Afterwards, she had me plug it back in. It now worked.

I'm very happy with this device now, but have some serious concerns about its durability and longevity since it could not work right out of the box. In addition, it lacks the privacy camera cover that the Echo Show 5 has. For these reasons, minus two stars.

All things considered, this sounds as about good as a very decent JBL speaker that was my previous favorite for music, and the screen is more vibrant than a Lenovo Smart Display. I'm happy with my purchase assuming it doesn't need to be unplugged for 2 minutes every time I want to use it.

Update: After having this about a week, sound completely stopped. I give up. I'm not going to unplug this for two minutes every time I need to use it. This thing is getting returned. Two defective units in a row does not give me confidence that Amazon has a quality product. This is in addition to being frustrated at the inability to turn off "Things to Try" messages. It's a beautiful display that looks cluttered with all of the nagging messages. So much potential here, but it is a failure.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stupid Reminders on how to use Alexa
reviews.reviewText:
Would have been a nice device to have but did you really have to put your "Try This..." into it.
Send it back after using it for only a few hours and spending a lot of time talking with Amazon techs to resolve the problem. After a number of calls to Amazon I was finally told you cannot get rid of Try This...
Stupid move on your part Amazon. Like a lot of other people commented: You can have a nice photo montage running and those idiotic Try This... keeps showing at the bottom of the screen.
Had high expectations for this device and you shot it out of the sky.... Nice move dummies

reviews.reviewTitle: Two steps forward and one step back...
reviews.reviewText:
I love my Echo Show (1st Generation) so why not the Generation 2? Since countless reviews have focused on the big and beautiful screen, my comments are added here:
1. No doubt this is a gorgeous screen. The small clock typeface has been fixed, although much to my surprise, there is little to no clock customization. Worse, the only background "themes" are the simplistic (and very tiring) "illustrations" and no background at all. What happened to the wonderful photos I have on my Show 1st Generation? This is Amazon's star product; I would have expected all kinds of new customization features and details. I settled for my folder "Album" of various photos that I have in my Amazon Photos app. Just say "Alexa, add this album to my background" and they will cycle every 1 minute or so (and no, there does appear to be any way to cycle these any faster...). Any yes, as another reviewer stated, an entirely different background pops up with an ad or notification.
2. The loud Alexa voice has been fixed I have read. I don't really like the side and rear speaker placement however - poor Alexa sounds as if she is within a box. The sound is indeed louder with an accentuated bass (and a three-level equalizer, woohoo!) but the music is missing a clear location. It sounds diffuse and non-distinct.
3. The worst surprise was this irritating screen-goes-blank after 2 minutes feature, which is carried over from the 1st Generation. Why does this happen? I can no longer see lyrics or title or the art after the screen dies. Arrgghh.
4. No Youtube. We all know why but that doesn't make it any better. And no, the Silk/Firefox work-around is just stupid. Just make up (Google and Amazon) and bring the native YouTube back!

In retrospect, I'm glad I have them both. The 2nd Generation will take over the kitchen and the 1st Generation goes with me to work.

Why all the critical comments despite the 4-stars? Because the new Echo Show is placed right next to my Lenovo Smart Display, which has a seamless Youtube and great sound/screen as well. The 2nd Generation Echo Show is just so much nicer than the Smart Display which was one of the biggest disappointments for me in 2018.

Amazon can quickly fix most of all these nit-picking comments in future updates. Give us more customizations in the GUI (backgrounds, themes, clock styles like the Echo Spot), fix the blank-screen irritation, and PLEASE bring back Youtube!

reviews.reviewTitle: Issue with many new units sent out July 2019
reviews.reviewText: Bought this on Amazon Prime day on July 15, 2019. I have all the other Alexa's in my home and set up is usually very easy. This was very difficult, it took us hours to get the sound working and that was turning it on and off and resetting the device numerous times. It worked for one day and then stopped. Called customer service the next day and they stated that many of the devices that were sent out for Prime day are not working properly and there is no volume. The resolution I got was, hold on to it for four or five days and hopefully they will do an update to fix it. No suggestion to send it back or send a new one. Basically keep your fingers crossed and hopefully Amazon will fix the problem on the hundreds of units that have already complained about this issue. When you're playing a video and tell Alexa to stop, it does not stop. You literally have to scream at it to go back to home. The suggestions and captions all day long scrolling are really really annoying, you should be able to change this! Putting your photos on in the slideshow doesn't work properly either. You constantly get Amazon backgrounds coming up. What a disaster this was in ordering! You would think a brand new item they would at least let you send back. Like I want to wait 5 days and hope that the problem gets fixed with an update? How can hundreds of units go out like this? This was a very unprofessional and horrible mistake on Amazon's part.

These were very expensive given the fact that they come with this mini 7 page manual that doesn't explain anything. When I tried to call support, I was connected to someone overseas. If you've ever experienced this there's no need for me to explain the frustration. If they don't want all 4 of the echo shows I just purchased returned, a native English speaker will contact me via the phone number connected to my account.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great display, great sound quality, pretty mediocre software / features
reviews.reviewText:
I already had an Echo Dot in my kitchen, but I thought the Echo Show would be nice to have in there so I could see timers, watch some videos, see recipes and I liked that it could act as a digital photo frame as well. The original show was pretty dated looking so I skipped it, but the (2nd gen) Echo Show looks so much better.

Software:
This is the biggest problem with the Echo Show so I'm leading with it. The software is really designed poorly. If it has a huge 10" touch screen, why not design the software to let you use touch AND voice. Want to go to a website? You can't just click on a browser, you have to ask it to "Open Firefox" or "Open Silk". Want to quickly pull up a list of your timers currently running? You can't, you have to ask it. Want to search from a Prime Movie to watch while cooking? You have to do it with your voice and it's very cumbersome. If you're watching a video and want to set a timer, it closes out the video. When a timer is running, it's not always displayed, so you are left wondering how much time is left and have to ask her. When you use it as a photo frame (using the Prime Photos app on your phone or computer) the photo you use is muted (no where near as nice looking as it is on the Google Home Hub) and it's constantly you to "Try asking Alexa to....". The whole thing is really poorly designed from a visual perspective. Thankfully that can be solved with software updates if Amazon tries.

Display:
The screen is beautiful and viewable from anywhere in the room. I find it to be a good size, in fact, it was one of the reasons I didn't go with the Google Home Hub. With a 7" screen, that was just too small to be useful.

Sound:
It's a huge upgrade from my Echo Dot. It has a nice full sound and I rarely have the volume over 40%.

Voice Control:
It does a great job at hearing the call phrase "Alexa" from anywhere in the room and even in adjacent rooms

Overall, it's a good device with a lot of potential. Hardware-wise, it's top notch. Beautiful display, great sound, fits in well in a kitchen. The software is just lacking. You have to wonder if the people who designed it ever tried to use it on a regular basis. Hopefully they'll address those in future software updates.

reviews.reviewTitle: disappointed - had hoped to play hulu on echo show and it does - perfectly!
reviews.reviewText:
Original Review 2-28-2019
Am very disappointed this does not work with Hulu...I get hulu to play but it buffers every 3 seconds- impossible to watch anything. Hulu streams perfectly on other devices.... 25 mbps internet is working well with all other devices.

UPDATE: MAR 1 2019 a day after the above post, my echo show appears to be streaming GREAT. Must take 24-36 hrs to get updates installed, etc. I bought the echo show to replace a regular echo that my elderly sight impaired mom uses. It sits by her bed. The screen is beautiful on full bright. Of course the echo show does everything the echo did but since she has some sight she can look at Hulu news programs on TV up close while in bed. It works great for her and her caregivers who have her schedule linked via google calendar, favorite music, arlo cameras to see who is at the door, etc. The schedule displays in large font on the screen. Hearing your sight impaired ninety something yr old mom wake up and be able to ask "alexa, whats on the calendar" and not feel so helpless is a wonderful gift.

March 20, 2018: going back to 2 stars. For those buying this mainly to stream Hulu: Dont. It works only intermitantly. I have adequate wifi and know all the right settings on the Alexa app. About 70% of the time when asked "alexa, tune into CNBC on hulu" she repeats and does nothing. Only sometimes does she connect. Am tired of getting on the phone with Amazon and Hulu techs with them each pointing fingers at the other.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not nearly as useful after Amazon hobbled Amazon Music
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this to help my father (who has Parkinsons Disease and whose hands are not longer able to operate a CD player) listen to his language learning CDs (which I bought on Amazon, ripped to MP3 and then uploaded to Amazon Music).

Amazon - after touting this exact feature ("You can listen to all your music!") - then abruptly hobbled Amazon Music so you can no longer use it to play your own uploaded music, even if you bought it legally from Amazon in the first place (as I did). No explanation, just dropped it.

If you want to play exactly what Amazon tell you you can listen to, then this might work. And if you want an easier way to spend more money on Amazon, then go ahead. But they've hobbled Amazon Music and who knows what else they may just decide to drop from the Echo if it doesn't match their business objectives in the future.

Customer centric company? Alexa tells me different.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic Successor to the First Generation Show
reviews.reviewText:
We love the Alexa Show 1st generation and have had it for over a year.
I can truly say the Show 2nd generation is a worthy upgrade if you listen to music on it.
The audio is fantastic with lush deep low end and richer mid-range and highs.
We listen to a lot of music in our kitchen with ours and this one thing makes it so worthwhile to me.
The screen is noticeably larger and looks like it is higher resolution.
Watching movie trailers or shows is even better.
I can only imagine that one day there will be small TV sized Alexa Shows. I would love to replace the 27" TV that is on the wall right behind the Alexa Show with a larger screen Show 3 or whatever is in the pipeline. I can have a Fire TV stick on it but that is different than the Show. It doesn't pop up tidbits of information nor wake to "Alexa". Perhaps a Fire TV Cube would work, but again it has a bit of a different feel than a Show. I think the Show is the perfect counter top or table device, so I guess what I'm asking is simply to have a Fire TV have a setting where it acts more like a Show. But then again my TV doesn't have motion sensors to know when you've walked into the room. Nor does it stay on all the time. - Maybe there is something to my wish after all.
Anyways, I am really impressed. If you already have a gen 1 Show then you may be fine to keep with it. I'm giving mine to my Mother-in-law so we can video chat with her. It will be more than enough for her needs. But if you listen to music a lot or really want a larger screen then the Show 2 delivers on those. 5 Amazing Stars!

reviews.reviewTitle: 2nd Gen - If only the software lived up to the screen and speakers...
reviews.reviewText:
I have been trading in my original Echo Show and Echo Spot devices for the Show 2nd Gen and Show 5. Sound quality on the 2nd Gen, superior - you might not even miss a Sonos Play One (which I also have for my TVs) and this has an excellent screen. Sound quality on Show 5, far better than the Spot.

Screens on both devices far more useful than their predecessors. If you are trading in Spots, be aware that the Amazon base for the Spot will work perfectly on the Show 5. Saved us $20 x 2! Base is highly recommended if using for a nightstand clock unless your nightstand is lower than your viewing angle. Ability to have large clock on Show 5 is excellent for trying to view without the glasses at night. FAILURE to allow for a large clock on the 2nd Gen - for instance if using for a kitchen clock with photo background like the Show 5 has - inexcusable at almost 3x the price. Fix this Amazon. Clock on the 2nd Gen is unreadable across a large room which is a complete waste of that beautiful new large screen. I would like to have a slide show background behind a large analog clock, for instance. Perfect for the kitchen or family room.

Show 5 has a clock shutter - great for a bedroom clock. 2nd Gen is missing a clock shutter. Why? If you are setting the 2nd Gen on a shelf - in a family room for instance - be aware that if you intend to do video dropins you will need a base to lower the angle unless you like looking at the ceiling. The angle on these was designed for standing at the kitchen counter (just as long as you don't care that you can't see the clock) or sitting bolt upright at a desk with the device in front of you at arm's length. Any other height/angle combinations and you are going to need the base to get a proper view of the room. These devices are vast improvements over their predecessors - but - several missed opportunities for simple softrware value adds.

Glad to own these, but waiting anxiously for software fixes for some obvious misses on the 2nd Gen. The top of the line should have ALL of the features of the lesser devices available, not a subset of the Show 5. Amazon wrongly assumed that people would want a giant clock on a small screen but would have no use at all for a giant clock on a large screen . The great sound from the new speakers will soothe me while I wait for the software fix.

I bought this echo show to add some flavor to my nights in the kitchen. My wife of 36 years, and I love music, and we banter back and forth on things as we prepare dinner. I thought, Hey, an echo show would be fun........ Wrong! The first one I received didn't have any sound. I got tech support on the phone ( now that's funny) and they said "the speaker isn't working" I said ....Really? So they ship out another and it has the very same problem. Yes the very same issue. However, I was able to fix the problem by unplugging the unit, and plugging it back in. Yup that was it. unplug, replug. Now this happened while the SECOND tech support person was on the line with me. She says, : oh yeah, that's what I was going to have you do". NO she never mentioned that, and didn't even know I did it until there was sound coming from the unit. My point is this. I spent 250 dollars on the unit 128 dollars for Prime, 8 dollars for music. and wasted 3 hours of my time on two different nights sorting this out. GO WITH the Google home. I should have. and no I'm not associated with Google at all. I do not recommend you purchase this unit. It really, in the end, isn't worth it. I was excited to get one and all that excitement is now GONE! I really haven't used it since the first night. Don't really want to. If you want to buy it off me I'd be glad to get rid of it. Funny how Our time has no value to these merchants, never will.

reviews.reviewTitle: Huge improvement over the first version
reviews.reviewText:
Look, this is a beautiful product. Huge, High Def screen, great sound, etc. The only negative is - we're still waiting for fun exciting things to do with it. We hooked it up with LifX lights, Ring doorbell and cameras, and the new Amazon plugs. All that is great, you can turn things on and off, but with the exception of the Ring video, not much needs the beautiful screen.

We use it to video chat with the kids & grandkids, and I think the stationary, hands free Echo is better for video chat than having to hold a phone. But let's get some more fun and interesting video content going!!
Terrible!!! Doesn’t “listen” as well as other devices. And if you want to use it for music eat all, the speakers/sound quality is far worse than a dot or other.

Ordered it by voice yesterday (20 Nov 18) and got it on my door next day in less than 20 hours, thanks prime. Took about 10 min to do updates and everything and since I already have a Alexa account for my other devices it was preregistered and automatically connected to internet.

The sound is amazing the attached video doesn’t do it justice. It has a pretty good sound wilder and IF you open a new card it’s 70 dollars off with a gift card so affectively after taxes I only paid 119 for it. You have to order by voice to get the early Black Friday price plus 10 dollars off first Alexa voice purchase then that’s how u get that 119 price line. Either way love it so far. Works perfectly with my nest camera. Takes no longer than the nest app to open up and show me on the screen.

Sound wise I’d say it could used some extra power in the mid range but still a very powerful speaker. That’s all based on the past hour playing with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lack of ability to play Youtube videos is terrible, Ring integration is weak, voice pickup not good
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the gen 2 Alexa Show with the aim to use it in the kitchen, to use it as a screen for some Ring devices, and to view web videos when I'm cooking.

Big issues:
Ring integration: The Ring integration sucks. When motion is detected or a doorbell press happens, you should have the option to have the Show automatically display the Ring camera that's reporting in.

Web video: I had aims to use the device to watch Youtube videos and read about the workarounds that exist for the device inexplicably not having a Youtube app (due to some Amazon tiff with Google). I thought I could get around this by using the integrated browsers, but this really doesn't work well. The browsers seem to expunge cookies every time you switch to the home screen, so you get logged out. Youtube, Youtube TV and DirecTV online viewing are basically non-starters. Who the heck uses Hulu?

Audio mic: Our old first gen Alexa (not the show version) had no issues understanding us when being asked to do something. This gen 2 Alexa Show has a much harder time picking up requests and many times we have to repeat the requests multiple times before it figures it out.

Lack of recipe content: There are tons of simple recipes that I ask for that just aren't found. This highly touted functionally of this device pretty much stinks.

On the plus side, the sound quality is pretty good. The screen looks fine and is bright enough.

reviews.reviewTitle: Try "Echo, stop telling me what to try!"
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this echo show to both entertain and keep an eye on my senile grandmother. I assumed it would be nice to choose photos to show her while also having a somewhat automated video chat option she didn't have to learn to use. Simple solvable software choices made by Amazon make this desire impossible

Before this purchase I'd been an avid regular Echo user, I have one if every room of my home with all my lights, music and other electronics fully controlled by voice and found it convenient to reorder items.

However, the words showing up on the echo show telling users what to try have completely ruined the opportunity to use this device as I describe above. My grandmother regularly becomes confused and aggravated after having been prompted to do stupid things ("Try, 'Echo' play Seinfeld on Hulu" prompting her to sign up for the service) or emotionally irresponsible things ("Try, 'Echo' call Mom?" which prompted me to have to explain to her that infact her mother had died years ago, again.)

It is stupid that I have to leave an emotional review about this, there should be a menu option to remove text prompts, the online forums are full of this complaint but Amazon is too busy abusive warehouse workers and monopolizing cloud storage for all mainstream internet use.

While the hardware is very nice -- loud, clear speakers, decent camera, large, bright screen with good viewing angles, unobtrusive design -- the biggest selling point for the Echo Show over the other Echo family of devices as is needlessly underutilized: The screen, while nice, is an afterthought.

The majority of all functions will only give you an audio response only, even if there easy to find corresponding video available from the same sources the Echo Show is pulling from -- news briefing from different media outlets, as an example. For video streaming, the big players either aren't available or require jumping through several hoops in order to get them to function. If you'd like to utilize the device as a digital picture frame, you're able to use Amazon Photo -- a thing no actually uses as far as I can tell -- but unable to link the device to any image services or accounts which people actually use.

Most of my gripes there aren't necessarily Amazon's fault as other companies are certainly under no obligation to create skills linking to their services for the Echo Show, particularly when many of them are direct competitors of Amazon and their services. It's unfortunate and frustrating, but it is what it is.

My main complaint is one which Amazon has no one to point a finger at but itself: The screen is 10" worth of unused space 90% of the time, with only 1/12 of the area being used to display the sort of information you'd want at a glance on an always-on display. It shows you the current time and temperature, but there is currently no way to customize or add additional information. Not the current day or date, upcoming scheduled appointments, particular stocks, moon cycle or whatever other info you might want at a glance.

To repeat, this $230 always-on display does not allow you to have the current day or date displayed. You need to ask Alexa to tell you this information. There is less information display on a 10" display than what is offered on the ~1" screen of you smartwatch of choice. There is no way to customize this information. This is less functionality than your average digital clock. To add insult to injury, apparently the ability to display the current day and date IS available on the Echo Spot for $100 less.

This may seem to a minor issue, and largely I think it is. But it speaks to the sort of decisions -- or lack thereof -- being made with this device as a whole. Amazon hit gold with the original Echo and decided to slap a screen on it, but don't seem to know what to do with the screen, even when it comes down to the most basic functionality.

If these sort of things are added in a future update, I will happily change this review.

I wanted a small screen that would play amazon prime movies and television shows. The reason is to be able to fall asleep to shows I already know (basically, bore myself to sleep) and that would not have a lot of flickering light levels. I have and echo show 1 which would --after all kinds of machinations---allow me to get to prime television, and would automatically take you to something, but not anything you asked for. Then you can try to back out and get to what you want. I wanted Murder, She Wrote, for example. It just kept saying it could not find it. If you could get to something you wanted, it would boot you out after a short while. So I decided to get the Echo Show 2. Same thing! I finally called support since this is the same behavior my echo show 1 was exhibiting so I figured software, not hardware. I spent a long time on the phone, and the fellow finally agreed that these just don't work for what I want it for. He could not get the machine at his premises to do anything I was asking. He thought it might be the comma in the tv show title. He said he would do a write up on it and someone should be in touch with me when solved. After a couple of weeks I just returned it since I heard nothing. The good news is, this was a refurb and it DID include the power cord that many said were missing from their refurbished purchase. So I am back to echo show 1.

I have been using the 1st generation for almost a year. This was on sale for a solid price. I’ve been using echo devices since the first one came out in early 2016. And it’s still in use over 3 years later.

I really like this 2nd generation so far.

The initial process to get it going took maybe 20 or so minutes because it had updates.

What do I like about this over the 1st generation? Here is a few things:

1. The sound. The sound is a lot more fuller for the room that it’s in. The bass is substantially better. It fills the room with plentiful sound. I live in a attached home and probably wouldn’t put it past 40 percent or so. The thing Gets LOUD.

2. The screen. It’s about 3 inches bigger than the first gen. And it’s way more vibrant. Although my ring camera footage is a bit grainy to be honest. I feel like it might be a bit better on the 1st gen. But most things the extra real estate really helps. If you have weak vision like I do, it really helps you see the screen from the other side of the room.

3. Most of the Same features in a bigger form factor. Still has the same home screen as the 1st gen. I have always enjoyed the home screen. I look at the days headlines as well as the time and current temperature. I have a smart home I guess you can say. I like that I can check my Ring cameras and get a visual view of the current brightness on my Hue light bulbs. Initially I was hesitant about getting one with the screen, but I really do love it. Also things like song lyrics and answers to questions give you something visual to look at rather than just hearing it

I noticed that this uses about 30 or so percent more power. Echo show 1st gen has a 21W AC adapter and this 2nd gen uses 30W. But if you factor in the extra 3 or so inches for the screen, the 9 watt increase seems about right.

So that’s just a few things that I have observed. I will try to update my review over time.

Personally I probably wouldn’t of bought it at MSRP price. Echo devices drop in price pretty quick. The lower price point influenced my decision. Lastly, I will continue to use my Older Echo devices because they seem to last a while. They just don’t go bad after a year or so.

Overall good buy for me. 2nd generation has improved on several things for sure.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's an exercise in frustration with some glimmers of greatness
reviews.reviewText:
I've had the Echo Show for a month now and there are things I like which are pretty much the things I like about any Echo device (I have 4 now). I like being able to access Apple Music from almost any room in the house and listen to almost any song I can think of. I had hoped the Echo Show would be the same for video. Sadly no.

I replaced the Echo in my kitchen with the Show. I wanted to be able to watch the news or a TV show while cooking which is something I love to do. A glass of red wine, watching a dumb action movie and making a nice dinner is my idea of heaven.

Unfortunately, beyond the limitations of only having easy access to Prime video and Hulu (you can access YouTube and Netflix more manually), the real problem is the impreciseness of the voice controls. I've spent the last 15 minutes trying to figure out how to watch Season 4 of the Vikings on my Echo Show. Hulu has it, but everytime I ask to watch, "Vikings Season 4, episode 1" the Show brings up the correct search and offers to stream it through Prime or Hulu. Perfect, right?

No, because although the search says Vikings Season 4, Episode 1 - if I select Hulu then I get Season 1, Episode 1. If I select Prime, I get the 1960's movie with Kurt Douglas (admittedly great but I've seen it a bunch). Herein lies the problem, I can't get to the content I want through the clumsy interface and simply opening Hulu ONLY shows a very limited selection of things to watch. 1st world problems, I know, but still.

Basically, the Echo Show has me getting mad at Alexa all the time. The radio version of her is pretty smart. Give her the TV remote and she's dumb as a box of rocks.

I'm disappointed with this product. It's way over priced for the amount of functions that it offers, or should I say what it is incapable of offering!
I should've stuck with the regular echo for $200 cheaper!

plug it in, went through all the procedures for connecting NO SOUND, called AMAZON HELPLINE went through all the suggested walk through still no SOUND, FINALLY clerk on the line (sounds like a call center) tells me they are working on an update and will automatically send me the updates, whisky tango foxtrot.

The Echo itself was mainly purchased to use with Ring doorbell (A gift from my daughter since I live alone).Without the Echo it took a long time to see who was at the front door thanks to the Echo Show I can access Ring much faster.The picture is great and the sound is excellent,no problems there.I purchased this when it was on special and you got a free Dot HOWEVER there was a catch there that Amazon failed to mention.Since I used the pay in installment option the so called "free "Dot was not included.The CSR at Amazon was not helpful at all and told me I could return it but that's all they could do.Of course I did not return it since I need it for Ring.I am very disappointed in Amazon for not being clear on that.Personally,I think the Echo Show is over priced so if they had of included the "free" Dot it would have made it easier to swallow paying that price.Amazon , you can do better than this,right?The endless ads on the screen are a pain and take away from whatever screensaver you are using.Only good points are clear picture and good quality sound but,if I wanted to watch a movie,I will use my laptop with a much bigger screen.And as mentioned before,Alexa often misunderstands me and I speak clearly and enunciate words properly. Also, heavy to take room to room.Oh, and did I mention overpriced with annoying ads on front of screen....of course I did!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice smart display with some bugs to shake out
reviews.reviewText:
It set itself up. Honestly, it knew which WiFi network to use and the password (assume Amazon has it stashed in the cloud somewhere under my name). So that was nice.

Watching Prime video works fairly well, but it can be hard to get exactly what you want without interacting with the touch screen (or possibly the remote, haven't tried that for anything but volume). On some shows and movies, it insists on bringing up a list of episodes, which can be scrolled through by intoning "next" and "previous" over and over. Other content plays immediately, picking up wherever I left off.

Hooked up Hulu as well, and telling the thing to "watch Seinfeld" worked automatically, bypassing Amazon Video where I don't have the rights. It picked up where I last left off and was able to advance episodes with "next episode", but "previous episode" unceremoniously dumped me on a Hulu list. Saying "next episode" on last episode put on to another series that is apparently part of "My Stuff" on Hulu.

Added the Echo Recast for off-the-air, which also works fairly well, but oddly enough it tries to launch Hulu to watch CBS. That doesn't work as I don't have Hulu Live. Oddly, NBC loads right up and ABC presents a poser: use Recast or Hulu. Telling it "1" for Recast works, but it would be nice if it would remember such decisions (with an interface to reset defaults). Using the "channel guide" command shows all of the expected channels (including CBS), so it's a bit of a mystery as to why it thinks CBS is only available on Hulu.

As for YouTube, the first command I tried was "watch cat videos" to see how bad the YT experience would be (thanks to a feud between Google and Amazon). Should have realized that the command didn't invoke YT at all. Later on asking for YT content, I was asked to choose between Silk or Firefox browsers. Choosing the former allowed for using YT through the touch screen. Suspect content integration is non-existent, though it should be able to at least search. Haven't bothered as YT is mostly a waste of time anyway.

Interfaces with the usual Alexa suspects of shopping (of course), checking the calendar, managing lists, setting alarms and timers, listening to music (now with lyrics), reading Kindle books, etc. are enhanced considerably by the screen. Phone calls worked as expected with an added visual interface; same for home automation. However, it seems that most 3rd party skills do not take advantage of the screen.

Speaking of home automation, I don't see a visual interface for setting scenes, but suspect they will work through voice.

No sign of notifications. Every other Alexa device I have lights up and beeps to indicate a new message. Would seem like a no-brainer to put these on the screen. Or perhaps the rotating display on the home screen covers these sorts of missives (mostly shopping related).

Sound is great, video looks great as well (though 720p I think).

Certainly this is the best alarm clock ever.

I have the previous version of Show as well as this new one. The sound is much improved and the monitor is great sized compared to the original. The biggest disappointment here is with the video interaction. Simply put, its a fail. I was looking forward to the Hulu option and even signed up for a new subscription just for this device. That said, the interface is essentially non-existant. its just awful. When watching on my ipad, i can access a full schedule, but on Show, there is no such option, only a list of the channels....doesnt even show what is currently playing. this product will never succeed if they dont address this video streaming fail. sad.

I was looking forward to receiving this, to use in my upstairs office to have videos and news shows on while I work. (as well as other things, since I already own three echo dots and love them) But after I got it plugged in and went through the installations, configurations and updates, there was NO SOUND. I looked in settings, all volume was up and enabled. There was NO documentation on sound issues, and no indication I would have to purchase external speakers. Shocking how little information there was on the issue in the tiny pamphlet included. IMMEDIATE RETURN.

I have used Alexa since the first one and I am delighted with the new Echo Show. The prior generation looked dated out of the box and featured a small screen, but it was the best version of a smart home speaker out there. When I opened the box to this one, I was impressed with the stylish design, beautiful front screen with no unsightly speaker under the screen like the prior model, and crisp sound. It is a wonderful device, and if you have the prior Show, it is a worthy upgrade!

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice upgrade but Bluetooth connection sucks
reviews.reviewText: I really like this upgrade but it has the same problem (if not worse) than the first generation - the Bluetooth connection sucks. I have a Fire Tablet which I use for movies and music and when I pair with my soundbar it is perfect. Whenever I pair the Echo Show with the soundbar it continues to cut out frequently. I had the same problem with my first gen Echo Show but not this bad. I had to go back to using my regular Echo with the soundbar to get a good sound again. Whatever technology they installed in the Fire tablet and the Echo I wish they would pass on the Echo Shows because it just does not work. My whole house runs on Alexa including thermostat, sprinklers, lights, etc. so I love the overall product - just not the Bluetooth so I can not fully recommend you buy it unless Bluetooth is not important, then it is superior in every other way.

New Echo Show 2nd generation, arrived defective: no sound whatsoever!
Upon installation, it updated its software, connected to wireless, but no audio. Checked that it wasn't muted and that mic was on.
Did factory reset, still no audio.
Sending it back to Amazon.
Anyone else having this problem with this batch?

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing sound from the new Echo Show!
reviews.reviewText:
The sound quality you get will blow you away! This is our first experience with the Echo Show since we didn't pick up the first generation. Luckily though I didn't miss out on the newest version since my wife surprised me with the preorder a couple days ago and man am I impressed with it.
We have ours in the bedroom, it serves as our alarm, smart TV, voice assistant and smart speaker. Everything it was meant for. I could see it being used in a kitchen setting too if you've used Alexa to help with cooking.
We have several Echo devices around the house including the Echo Plus in our living room where we started our smart home experience. The Echo Plus has some great sound quality don't get me wrong, but the Show definitely is the better sounding system. Adding this bad boy to our inventory of Echo devices was a great choice. You should do the same. Enjoy.

I’m not technologically incompetent by any means...
I have hooked up close to 20 Alexas and echo dots .. I ordered this echo show on prime day and I set it up ( it was already pre reg’d to my Alexa device account) it connected to the WiFi at our house but I can not get any sound of of this device. It can hear me commanding but I can’t not hear anything. I took all other devices offline and off blue tooth but still no luck ! Amazon please offer advice and instructions

If you like the original Echo Show, you will love this upgrade. The screen is gorgeous and the sound is incredible.
I received this device a couple of days ago and hadn't yet gotten around to installing it.
On this Saturday afternoon, I was in a Genisis mood. I asked Alexa to play Second Home by the Sea on my Everywhere group (which includes my original model Echo in my bathroom and the newest generation Echo in my kitchen and the newest generation Echo Dot in my laundry room.
Never a surprise, everything sounded wonderful.
Then I decided to dig in and install the new Show.
The installation was falling down easy. I had also purchased the adjustable stand, which was a cinch to attach to the new device. I went through the obligatory first-boot software upgrade and after a few minutes, my Alexa website interface was communicating with my new Show and I was able to alter my everywhere group to include it.
I played the same song. It was amazing. Fans of Genisis know that it is bass-intensive. This new Show thumps quite well for a device of its size.
I look forward to deregistering my old Show to gift it to a friend at work.
This upgrade is outstanding.

reviews.reviewTitle: Find myself constantly telling Alexa how dumb she is.
reviews.reviewText: So I had high hopes for the echo show, and have been met with frustration on many levels on many occasions. First, if you’re not VERY specific, you’ll probably get “hmmm, I don’t know that”. So then you’ll go through a dozen different ways of saying the same thing, before it will finally “get” it. It’s not intuitive at all. It should have come with a manual stating exactly how you have to say something in order to get it to work. Try adding multiple lights in the same room to a group so you can turn them all on or off at once. Do it perfectly the first time, or you’ll find yourself telling it a dozen times what you want, only to have it repeat the wrong thing back to you. Over. And over. And over. Amazon needs to hire someone to program these things that actually understands how to account for the multitude of ways people may want to program it to accomplish the tasks they want, without coming up with a “hmmmm, I don’t know that”.

I purchased this Show 2nd gen and two Show 5s. The (big) show was installed in my 87 yr old mothers home. She has advanced arthritis in her hand, is totally deaf in one ear & can’t hear out of the other. She also suffers from cataracts so her vision is less than ideal. To try and communicate via telephone is extremely difficult. Her landline is almost useless. She cant see god enough to use a smartphone so we’re left with a poor quality flip phone with a really weak speaker. Since installing the Show gen 2 in her home it’s changed her life for the better, it really truly has. The sound is so bold & clear that she has no problems at all hearing calls. The touch screen is very sensitive, just a light touch make the selection. My mom is very picky and normally resistant to change and was suspicious of this new technology.
She really likes her new (video phone) it’s won her over. It’s big & loud & intuitive.
I now have no problem communicating with her several times a day using the two Show 5s I purchased.
This is one of the best purchases I’ve made in quite a while.
I highly recommend both the echo show second generation and echo show five.

Love this product! It’s fun and functional! I know people worry about “the man listening to his/her conversations” . Well, I have absolutely nothing to hide. If you have nothing to hide, what’s the big deal?!? Seriously people, we are walking around with smart phones as an extension of our arms!!! “They” (whomever THEY”) are already are listening!! This product simplifies our life. In the dark, I am not breaking my neck fumbling around for a light! Alexa turns the light in for me! Every night she helps me go to sleep by playing white noise, she sets my alarms and she plays games with my family!! I haven’t even begun to access all the great things Alexa does. I get weather, news and I don’t have to YELL to call my family down for lunch or dinner!! She makes my lists and she reminds me of everything. My hubby didn’t want to like her but he uses her!!! She reads recipes for me.. she tells me when my amazon delivery is here. It works exactly like it is supposed to! LOVE this product. I haven’t had any issues with it. Easiest product I have ever used.

I really wanted to give this 5 stars but could't based on a huge lack of customization, specifically to the home/standby screen. The Show lacks no built-in wallpaper or background choices like the Spot does, no color adjustment for the standby clock. The "Try Alexa" messages at the bottom of the screen are shown no matter what you are looking at on the screen. This is my biggest complaint which I hope amazon can get rid of or at least have a toggle in the menu to turn on/off in a software update. Very disturbing to see when you are watching or reading something. Otherwise sound is very good with ample adjustments, web browser silk and firefox enabled work ok. Hope to update to 5 stars if amazon can get it right with a software update quickly! Google home has the display nailed!

Brand new Echo Show ordered on Prime Day. Zero sound. Saw some online forums this week with other consumers reporting the same issue. Have tried rebooting device and triple checking Bluetooth/WiFi. So disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Give me a 1st Gen Show over a 2nd Gen Show any day of the week and twice on Sundays.
reviews.reviewText:
I love all my Alexa devises and my 1st Gen Alexa Show is Great "The Star " so why is it that when a purchased the 2nd Gen Show I got a 4yr old, drunken, dyslexic pirate?
It does Not play my videos when I ask. it simply repeats my request in the form of a question over and over again " Do you want me to play Aquaman?" 4,5, 6 times. When I ask it took at
When I ask Alexa to play Boston Legal from prime Videoes, I get "Playing Boston Legal" and then it returns to Home Screen.
Asking The Show to turn on or off a light or device, that when it's dyslexia must kick in because my new 2nd Gen Show cannot find the lights or devices. Requesting to see my video library, I get about 1/5th of my shows. The rest of my library gets lost but that's ok because the show 6 out of 10 times will not play them. I GIVE THIS REVIEW AS A TRUE AMAZON LOVER AND PRIME MEMBER WITH OVER 22 AMAZON DEVICES. WHAT WHENT WRONG?
Bye the way on day 3 after I called in with my series of complaints they sent me a replaceplement 2nd Gen Show. Same Issues!
I am going to send this POS back and get my 1st Gen Show out of the kitchen and return it to my nightstand, and all my problems will disappear with the UPS truck that shows up to take this back.
Just as a small sidenote, this will be the first Amazon device that I have ever regretted buying, and that actually made my life worse. I originally purchased the 2nd Gen Show because I have ALS / Lou Gehrig's Disease, and I wanted to watch my videos on the 10.1 inch HD screen, when I go to sleep every night on my side. I guess it's back to the smaller yet far better working 1st Gen Show. Too many issues with 2nd Generation Show to give it my recommendation or a passing grade.
Beware!

I wouldn't waste my money on this again unless someone else you know already has one. Just get the Facebook portal where you can call/video and it has alexa built in. This product is not worth it and I would return it if they didn't have a 7 day return policy. Doesn't even play the songs I ask it to either (using VEVO). Supposedly you can video chat on skype but surprise you have to pay for it! AND it doesn't even work. You would think being the 2nd generation that it would be a lot better than what it is. I own 4 other echo devices and the only thing different about this one is you can see/hear what its talking about rather than just hearing it.

I thought I would love it. . . I started with google but the speaker died 8 months later and customer service was horrible... so I switched to amazon Alexa. I like the speakers a lot, but I have spent more hours then I care to admit with customer service on the devices with camera's. The camera is fuzzy when your drop in... it takes several moments to clear up... sometimes longer.
Hulu works great... Spotify works great... asking questions, great, custom service is great and they are so fast to respond, they switched out the device, they just don't know how to fix it.
nothing else works...
No Netflix, prime, Plex, sometimes the browser its self is less then helpful.... and the device freezes up. today it started beeping for no reason. I couldn't figure out why. I finally factory reset it and it stopped...
I don't know why this has happened but unfortunately I would not recommend this to anyone just because it has been a headache. just use a computer, tablet or something else...

If something changes I'll update this review.

The home screen constantly rotates messages for you to "Try" on the Show. It is distracting and useless. I would not have bought the Show if I had known about it in advance. It is like having a TV constantly display messages for you to try some product or another. Nobody would knowingly buy that TV. Whomever at Amazon thinks it is a good idea should be re-educated. Give the user an option to turn off that dumb message. My advice to all: don't buy the Show until they change this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't work with any TV features
reviews.reviewText: I have been able to set up several of the features the Echo Show is supposed to handle: smart bulbs, cameras, video calling and notifications. However, the one thing I bought it for was to be able to watch TV on it. I own two firesticks which work great, all you do is download the app for the channel you want then connect with your TV provider, but this is where the Echo Show gets stuck. I try to watch a channel and when I get to the screen to select my provider it doesn't react. I see my provider available in the list, I tap on it and nothing. I have even tried doing this step from the Alexa app on my phone but nothing. I am pretty disappointed because this was about half the reason I bought the thing in the first place.

reviews.reviewTitle: Serious defect in Show 1st Generation audio
reviews.reviewText: There are several discussion areas on the internet that address this issue, and it may start cropping up in 2nd generation Shows as well. This defect appeared in my 1st generation Show about six months after purchase. What happens is that a loud click or pop can be heard when the audio activates. Ask Alexa a question and you hear a pop before and immediately after the response. Play music or a podcast or any audio/video source, and within 5 minutes of starting, sometimes earlier, the pop/click appears randomly, though as the video clip shows it occurs on average about every 10 seconds while there is an audio source. You can avoid this distraction by using a bluetooth speaker, but my point of contention is that this is a defect that has not been addressed by the manufacturer. I purchased a 2nd generation Show before this issue cropped up with my 1st generation one so I can only hope that the defect has been addressed in the 2nd generation. If this issue were addressed I could easily give this product 5 stars since it has so many advantages over the various dots that I also own. I will not, however, be replacing them until I am convinced that this serious audio defect is addressed and corrected.

This product could be great. But it is not. The screen options are the main problem. Every 6 seconds a message pops up that says "Try Alexa ......" . This is not an option. You are just stuck with it. Every 6 seconds. It gets really annoying really quick. Amazon starting doing this with the Fire Stick 4k also. It stinks. Also, The screen times out and shuts off after a few minutes. Again this is not an option. You are stuck with it. If I want my screen to stay on that's too bad for me. I can't. Why would you even have a screen device and then just shut it off without the option to keep it on. I have to keep tapping the screen to wake it up. It stinks.

I upgraded from the Echo Show - 1st Gen to the Echo Show - 2nd Gen. The 1st gen software was upgraded to the same as the 2nd gen, so if you have the 1st, you won't need to upgrade to the 2nd to use the new software features unless.. you want the full screen and a much better sound experience.

The 1st gen device configuration was very poor with its boxy appearance and annoyingly prominent speaker location. The full screen presentation of the 2nd gen combined with the speaker moved to the rear is a winner and in my opinion, that alone is worth the upgrade but then I just like new electronics. The 2nd gen device looks better on the counter, it's sharp and easier to see text from across the kitchen because the screen is larger. The software update also centered the announcements on the screen which adds to the new look and makes it easier to read on the larger screen.
Netflix is not supported by this device. Unable to use Facebook messenger on the echo show 2. This device sucks. I expected more from this device, I really wanted to like it.

Purchased the show for my daughters and sons for Christmas gifts because I liked mine so well. Purchased the 2 for me. Always watching a movie or talking to the kids or great grands it’s always in use. Have a show in one bedroom and bathroom also as well as dots, echos and tap scattered throughout my rather large home and love them. The 2 sits in my kitchen. So in love with these products
I convinced employer to buy shows for use as intercom between offices. Perfect for yourself or as a gift. Will be gifting 2 two shows for Christmas gifts this year and more light bulbs for me. The 2 is very viewable. I especially like it has a built in hub so will be easy for gift recipients to hook up their own lights etc. wish it came with the stand

reviews.reviewTitle: A big improvment in every way
reviews.reviewText:
This is better I every way to the old first generation echo show.

The screen is better and clearer and if you love plenty of bass, this has it. The sound field is wide and will fill your room.

It turns on my philps hue lights on slightly faster also.

If you got the old show, the this is a worthy upgrade, everything about it is better, and for a 10" screen, because its so compact it does not look a monster like the Lenovo 10" smart screen, so love the smaller echo show form factor.

reviews.reviewTitle: wish I could return! Amazon blatant disregard of numerous complaints about Alexa "suggestions"
reviews.reviewText: How completely insane that you can't turn the Alexa 'suggestions' off!!! large bright white letters at the bottom of the screen "try asking Alexa to................" Arggghhh, what is the matter with you, Amazon!!!! Beyond annoying, and distracting!!! I bought 2 of these several months ago, but unable to set up till just now - what a mistake, as now I can't return them, which I would in a heartbeat, and buy Google instead! Amazon has RUINED an otherwise great and useful product, simply by being totally insensitive to their customers needs. (just read the huge number of complaints by users!!) I own 6 Echo dots, a Google Home, and lots of smart devices - but wish I hadn't wasted my money on the Show. I am very disappointed and angry with Amazon over this.

Nice package but really poor fidelity in sound. Bass is fluttery, grumbling at medium volume. Far from "Premium Sound". Video is excellent. Notations starting with "Try''.... are in such small print that you need to be sitting within arms reach to read easily. Backgrounds are nice but boring, especially the predominate color... pea green and faded blue. The background paintings/drawings are generally uninteresting. There is no indoor temperature sensor. There is a way to disable/enable the camera without disabling Alexa's monitoring ability.... just ask. "Alexa" could be way more intuitive and flexible in her understanding of questions and not require rote regurgitation of question formulation on subsequent questioning or requests. There must be some way that we humans can be relieved from Alexa's demand of complete and accurate remembrance/recollection of original task setup terminology for the myriad of tasks/requests we develop over time. We are not all "Watsons" but simple Earthlings. That's my review (so far) and I'm sticking to it.

I purchased this for my 85 year old mother. Was so excited that she could have face to face conversations with her children. What they don't tell you is that you have to have a smart phone in order to use the skype feature. If an elderly person had a smart phone, what would be the need to have this device? After hours of trying to get her skype to work, I left and went home trying to figure out why it wouldn't work. I finally connected her to my skype account using my smart phone. Problem is she still can't call me because it is like skyping with myself - aaarrrrrgggghhhhh!!!! I am hopeful that she will be able to skype with my siblings, but don't know yet. I don't know if my phone has to be near her device fo her to use my skype. DON'T BUY THIS IF YOUR PARENTS DON'T HAVE A CELL PHONE!!!!!

now my feeble old mom can use google calendar. The kids are happy sitting at the counter watching dora.. or I can watch football.

The main reason I got it was because my mom lloooooollolves to write stuff on a Calandar at home. The problem is.. I have no visibility of this at work.

She complained that she has to work visually... so she didn't like entering a shopping list on my amazon Tap.

Problem solved. She just says alexa. Add apples to the shopping list. Boom. Then later.. she can say alexa show me the shopping list. Boom. Visual. AND I can see it on my phone on the way home and I can pick stuff up.

Same play with ToDo list.

I am an Amazon Echo fanatic. From that very first Echo speaker tryout invitation to the 1st generation Echo show, I fell in love with Alexa products. So, when they announced a larger screen Echo Show, I pre-ordered like most people. I have had the product for a while now, and I must say that I am a bit disappointed.

Cons

The problems with the video feature.

First --- Alexa voice recognition on that is lacking. It takes more than one try to get the right video to play. I never had that issue with the first generation Echo Show.

Second --- Alexa does not pause or stop the video on command. I have tried several commands such as “Alexa, Pause!”, “Alexa, Pause the video!”, “Alexa, Stop!”, “Alexa, stop the video!.” The only thing that works is to command Alexa to play a song, then command it to stop the song. I wrote Amazon about this and never got an answer. I am not sure why, Amazon used to be so good at answering those questions, but this time around, I got no help.

Third --- Alexa does not pick up where you left off. When I get up and use the screen to pause a video when I come back the entire video is gone, and the screen is back to normal. I then have to ask Alexa to play the video again. This would not have been a problem, but if it is a show that you are re-watching, you have to remember the specific season and episode you were watching to ask Alexa to play for you. It is a frustrating issue and still need improvement.

Pro

I love the sound system. I know that at the beginning people were complaining, I guess I lucked out because I never had an issue with the sound of the Echo show. I never go higher than volume 5 because I tried volume 10 once and it gets really loud. If a song with bass is playing, you can hear the bass super clear.

Alexa can respond well to many commands as its past contender. It can show you what you need to see or read it to you. I do not use the Audiobook feature because I do not like audiobooks. However, I did ask it to read me a book to see if it works. Alexa can only read you specific books. You must give it the title of the book in order for it to work. There are skills available for children that can select more random books. I have tried the Amazon Storytime feature, and it can read you random bedtime stories, which is cool. I wish there were one for adults, that can just read random books as asked but that just me being picky.
I love the fabric cover of the New Echo Show. My very first Echo show, I had to buy a cover to prevent it from being scratched and looking worn. The new fabric feature is perfect and easier to clean.

Overall, despite the drawbacks of the video feature, I will highly recommend the Echo Show 2. I use it often and still watch some shows and newsreel on it. I am sure, as past experiences have shown, that Amazon will soon correct those issue with the Echo. So, don't be afraid to invest in one.

There are LOTS of complaints, and rightfully so, about the truly annoying "things to try" tips that constantly scroll across the screen 24/7. As of now, as far as I know, there is no way to disable this stupid feature. BUT there's one that's even WORSE! I have set up a slideshow that displays personal family photos on my Echo Show. It's pretty nice. A digital photo frame.

The thing that SUCKS about it is that for every 3 or 4 of my photos that get displayed, Alexa inserts a photo of some prepared food dish and offers me the recipe. If I WANT recipes, I know how to find them online. I don't need them popping up every 30 seconds in my family slideshow. What the hell is wrong with Amazon? First, they ignore the THOUSANDS of complaints about the "thing to try" bullshit, and now they hijack your personal slides to show you pictures of food!

I know Jeff Bezos isn't interested in my advice on how to sell products, but these stupid, annoying features should, at the very least, be optional. It's a quick software fix. Give us a switch to turn this shit off. Please! For this reason, I have discouraged friends and family from buying one of these devices unless they're willing to live with a billboard in their house advertising to them 24/7.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pretty cool but has some major flaws.
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this on the first day of Prime Day (yesterday), so props for the next day arrival.

The obvious - I doubt this is too many people's first Alexa device so I won't go into too many details. Alexa is good for a limited number of tasks out of the box: Timers, alarms, occasionally answering a question usefully, weather updates, etc. As a standalone totally not worth much money. I have mine paired with a couple of smart LED bulbs and a Logitech hub so it has a bit of actual functional use, turning on the TV/entertainment center and setting the lights to the right setting.

Specifically the the Echo Show:
Pros - sound is very good
Screen is nice
Alexa works like it does on any other device
Solid value at $160 plus a Hue bulb and Dot
Recipe idea looks cool and seems to work with a few minutes of testing.

Cons -
Basically the same as everyone else has written, but here goes:
Camera aims at the ceiling - should come with the stand Amazon is selling for $30
Always has text asking me to try some task
HULU plays a random episode of any TV show you ask it to play (edit - may not be random, just playing from first profile).
No YouTube
Can't make the time bigger on the homescreen
I can't seem to get it to interface with my FireTv. When I say "pause Hulu" or "pause FireTv" it doesn't do anything. It appears to be all setup correctly within the app. (Works with Netflix though by saying "pause Netflix")

Solid 4 stars - some presumably easy software updates would move this to a 5 for me. Only the camera is a physical defect.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do Not Buy; Horrible Quality Control
reviews.reviewText:
This is my second Echo Show, and the second one that does not work right. Bottom line up front: No sound comes out of this one, and yes, the volume is up and I've tried completely resetting it.

I had the 1st-generation Echo Show, and its screen wavered and flickered incessantly (but unfortunately, that problem did not show up until after 30 days). I sent it back to be fixed, but all the "genius" Amazon techs did was reset it...which worked for about 30 minutes. Good job, Amazon techs!

Now this second one, a 2nd generation, doesn't work out of the box. Alexa acts like it's working. In other words, if you ask for the forecast, it'll show up as text on screen but there is no acknowledgement or sound. If you ask it to play music, the scroll bar will appear and be moving (and if she knows the lyrics, they'll display on the screen), but again, no sound.

Yes the volume is up, and I've tried unplugging and replugging, and a factory reset. (As a technical-type person, I can already tell you that the odds that a factory reset would fix this issue—or the earlier one with the flickering screen—asymptotically approach zero. That is, Amazon is just wasting your time when they recommend that for issues like this.)

I would not recommend an Echo Show to my worst enemy, although they might indeed make a great torture device.

Summary: Do not buy! And avoid at all costs. Amazon simply does not know how to make reliable devices with screens. (I have a non-screen Echo, and it's worked fine for years.) And their tech support is not good enough to make attempting to work with them worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Slightly underwhelmed but hopeful. Overall rating at this time: meh.
reviews.reviewText:
So, where to begin? How about with the Good:

Screen - nice size, bright and vivid

Sound - nice, room-filling sound

Unit design - nice aesthetics, but functionally lacking without a stand

-

As far as the Bad or weak points, there are quite a few, but fortunately these *could* be resolved with policy or software changes:

Performance - overall, it's a fairly sluggish compared to my other devices. This could be issues with code, hardware or servers - there's no way I can say for sure either way. Hopefully, it's something that can be remedied on the AMZ side.

Screen - there's not much to watch on it. Or rather, it's really hard to find anything worth watching. Your choices are Amazon Video or Hulu.
> No Netflix
> No casting from other devices
