> No Plex video (music works fine)
> No SlingTV (we're a Sling house, not a Hulu house)
> No YouTube (note - there's a workaround to get to YT by using an included browser, but it's slow and awkward.

Additionally, finding what you want on Amazon Video is painful on this device. Videos I can easily locate on a phone, tablet or set top box are nearly impossible to locate.

All in all, it feels a lot more like the Fire Phone than it does a Fire tablet, in that it seems geared more to sell stuff than it is to meet consumers needs or demands .

Unit design - as a counter-top device, it REALLY needs to be up off the counter a bit more. Otherwise, there's a good chance that at some point a spill will ruin it. I bought the ATOPHK stand for an additional $44 (ouch!). It's a great stand, but something like this really should be included with a "premium" product like this that is meant for the table/counter.

I bought this Echo Show because I love gadgets, but only because it was on sale. I wouldn't have purchased it at full price and, having bought it and experienced it's limitations first-hand, I'm not sure I would buy it again until the functionality/compatibility is expanded significantly. As it stands, a $29 Echo Dot connected to my home system via bluetooth has 90+% of the value I get from the Show.

Your mileage and desired usage may vary!

Note to Amazon: I *really* want to like this a lot more than I do. Tweak up the speed and give me more access to other sources and you'll have a 6-star product.

--

.:: 3-month update ::.

The above observations and opinions are unchanged, both good and bad. But I've found something else that I think is worth mentioning. I found that video surveillance of any kind is slow / delayed significantly. I've tried BlinkXT2's, as well as several budget-friendly Dericam cameras (via Monocle) and both had a serious 12-18 second delay on the Echo Show. For instance, the pizza delivery guy was ringing my doorbell before I saw his car pull in my drive.

There is nearly no delay when viewing the same video streams from either camera on the phone apps, both on wifi and off. Also, network monitoring shows my bandwidth is far from saturated. That being the case, I can say with a fair bit of certainty the issue is with the Show and not the cameras or network. My guess is there's a shoddy x264 codec in there somewhere, or the overall hardware's just not up to the task.

Either way, I'm keeping it at 3 stars for the looks and sound quality, but I'm still largely unimpressed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Review Based On If You Are A Echo Show 1st Edition Owner..
reviews.reviewText:
This review is solely based on my thoughts and advantages of upgrading to the new Echo Show 2.

Upgrade Pros:
- Sound Quality
- Bigger Screen

Outside of those two factors regards the Echo Show 2 I don’t see any further justification that would fall into upgrading your original Show to the Echo Show 2.

I did not see much a a listening skill improvement as sometimes I have to speak up to get Alexa to listen. I did get a lot more of “sorry, which device?” From Alexa when both Shows connected and yes they were of different rooms. I also have the Echo as well 2nd gen. I had issues with some skill sets built in with New Echo making connection or recognizing the demand.. Such as Apple Music , in which works perfect with my original Show but after connecting both, it seemed that I was consistently receiving the quote “ I cannot play Apple Music at this time” a lot.

So I asked myself is it worth just to upgrade to a tablet size screen? (The Show 2 is literally twice the size screen of the original Show)
Only thought of consideration for that would be to access view of security cameras, but even on that note, I have two IPads at 10 & 12” for that, so that was crossed off.

Lastly the sound, only real advantage here is if you don’t have a sound system or a sound bar then yes this would be ideal for you. Being that is not the case for me as I do have a soundbar, that was the last advantage that was removed in my book from keeping device and of course the device issues contributed the most to me overall to me. It also take up quite some space as the back end of it extends quite a bit due to most likely its hefty speaker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Continual Hounded by the "Things to Try" and It Can't Be Turned Off
reviews.reviewText: Returning it because of the constant "Things to Try" notifications on the home screen. I contacted Cust. Service and there's no way to turn that off. Also, it's lousy at playing anything online, like a video on YouTube. The voice and image do not sync up. Not happy with this device, it's going back tomorrow.

Pretty sure this will get returned. I want to like it but the primary reason I purchased was to watch shows from Hulu while I work in the kitchen and you cannot chose a specific season/episode. It just plays whatever it wants. There's no way to select it on the screen and after opening Hulu you can't tell it to "Play season 2 episode 10 of ......". It just plays the first episode of a season. If you tell it to play the next episode it just restarts the episode your on. Seems a tablet may be better suited for my needs but then Amazon shouldn't advertise that it works with Hulu. I also don't like that you cannot turn off the suggestions on the screen so when you have photos as your background there's always text across them. Makes me feel like I paid to advertise for Amazon in my home. A lot of the skills need much more fine tuning to be user friendly. For example Ring has a skill so I can see who's at my front door on the device but it takes several seconds to connect as it connects through the website. By that time I've already gone to answer it or pulled it up on my phone much quicker. It does have great sound though and picture quality but I don't think that makes up for the lack of being user friendly.

My main purpose for buying this was to use Skype to chat with my mom. Since chat is currently one of the few apps that allows group video chat, I thought I could chat with her and others at same time via the Echo Show. However please note that group chat via Skype on the Echo Show does not work. Only worked when did person to person video call. I feel there should have been some mention that if Echo supports Skype it does so without full features. I submitted a question before buying but nobody knew the answer to I'm writing this review to save others the need to buy then return.

Also not while the device itself is nice (big screen and great speakers) the software takes no advantage of having a screen for input purposes. You control this completely by saying "okay alexa" which for me personally isn't ideal. Also there were suggested videos that you had limit control over and really didn't want to see. Overall, they could have made a much better device if the software was applied differently on many fronts.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent at what it does. Just not sure that you NEED it.
reviews.reviewText:
As the headline mentions, this is a great device that is excellent at what it does. Its mics and Alexa integration are every bit as good as the audio-only Echos. Its audio quality is outstanding. My favorite use for mine is as a speakerphone when working from home in combination with my Echo Connect and home phone service. The screen is beautiful as well. Basically, I have no real complaints. If you're heavily invested in the Amazon ecosystem and can spare the $$, I think you'll find this to be a very nice compliment.

HOWEVER... I put this squarely in the camp of "nice to have" vs a real MUST have. It's not cheap. If you're looking to integrate Alexa into your home, you can quite literally put her in every room via the excellent 3rd gen Echo Dots and still have plenty of spare change vs the cost of one of these. While the display interface is nice enough, other than answering calls, I seldom find myself interacting with it because it's just as quick to ask for the simple things I need (ex.- Weather, Home lighting, Security cam feeds, etc.) by voice. It's mostly a nice enough photo frame with an excellent speaker. Having said that, the G**gle Home Hub that currently sits next to it is a far better picture frame due to its Ambient mode lighting adjustments and has the killer feature of Chromecast support. Almost any app not natively supported by the device itself can be casted over to the Home hub's display, and the HH can be integrated into more than one group for home audio playback (vs only a single group per device for the Amazon ES).

In summary, it really comes down to your own individual needs/wants and whether or not you've bought into either ecosystem. If you're already bought into the Google ecosystem, this one isn't for you. If you're a Google Play Music and/or heavy Youtube user with an Android phone, it isn't for you. BUT... If you love Alexa, it is. If you're looking for the one, killer device to bring Alexa into your home, this is it. If you want multiples and have a large house to cover, maybe you should start with the audio-only Echos and work your way up unless you get a killer price on one of these. All in all, Amazon did a great job with what they have here, and I'm confident they'll continue to improve it within the confines of what they can do as compared to Google.

We use one Echo Show (2nd Gen) downstairs and the other in our master bedroom to control lighting, front & garage door locks, Nest smart thermostats (2), Ring front door-bell camera, etc ... they have allowed us to retrofit, integrate and otherwise update our home into a "smart home". All these functions we are able to execute & control just by the sound of our voice ... simply by speaking commands to Alexa. Naturally, we can ask about the weather, temperature, celebrities, movies, etc ... anything you can type into Google we can now simply just ask Alexa by voice for the answers. The music quality is excellent as is the video quality ... we often play some of our favorite music via Alexa (all for free) and even can pull up our favorite music videos via YouTube / Vevo. This is an excellent product and everyone should have at least one.
We actually still have our original Echo that we now placed in our master bedroom bath and purchased two more Amazon Echo Show 5s for our kids' rooms ... so we can all control & use Alexa conveniently from nearly any parts of our home. And our son figured out that you can play the same music via all five of our Alexa products at the same time to "pipe" music throughout our home like the old fashioned intercom systems.
FANTASTIC PRODUCTS !!!

reviews.reviewTitle: returned & purchased google home hub, all my frustrations/issues are gone now.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this for integration with my security cams, to drop in on my kids echo (his room is some distance from the living area of the house), & I was happy to find out the rest of the features.

On major issue- major voice control quirks. I have to over enunciate to get it to work for nearly anything. I’ve given up on using it for my Phillips hue lights, it rarely works, and usually ends up asking me what I said multiple times. I have no accent, and my diction is clear, my career involved being heard by many over the radio, so I know that isn’t the issue.

There is a 3 to 5 second delay anytime I tell it do view my nest cameras, this is a dealbreaker, we had an intruder try to break in, and in that instance 4 seconds to identify the person smashing your front door feels much too long.

I’m beginning to wonder if I’ve got a defective model, it seems to have gotten more quirky after a couple initial weeks of trouble free use.

Drop in was a large percentage of why I bought this and the kid friendly module. That feature is a bust. We’ve got a spread out house, I’ve got to go through 3 security doors to tell the older kid to come to dinner. A voice activated PA sounded lovely. It. Doesn’t. Work. It is frustratingly slow, it squeals with feedback the entire time, and if he is listening to music, he seems unable to hear me at all. Sometimes I won’t disconnect, leaving me with dinner prep hands trying to get the squealing feedback to end. This feature is worthless.

Note- returning device. Issues have gotten more prevalent. We watched videos on the amazing screen the first day, but that’s it. We should have gotten the google home hub for the best support and intuitive smart device controls. Lesson learned.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality Product with some VERY irritating behavior which cannot be turned off...
reviews.reviewText:
Lots to like about this product:

1 Good HD Resolution, good color.

2. Automatically gets dimmer for sleeping, well implemented.

3. Great sound for such a small bedside table device, however, not as good as a high quality soundbar which you can connect too via bluetooth, so echo dot + soundbar actually better.

4. Good video playback, but appears to require a subscription to prime video.

5. Integrates well with Ring devices. This is the reason for my purchase. I tell my device to "show me the back yard" (or any other named camera) and it does, with a larger and better, and generally faster view than the Ring app on my cell phone. This is probably reason enough to purchase the item if you use the Ring system and cameras. It appears you can do two way audio from and to the cameras.

6. Nothing from Google (say Youtube) is available directly, however, you can ask alexa to "open google', at that point you can access your email, youtube, and all other google services via the built in Firefox browser.
No other streaming appears available without additional cost.

1. The biggest irritation for me, and one that could be easily fixed (and would probably result in a 5* review if it was fixed):

On the bottom of the home screen, below the nice nature shot you have posted from your camera, the device insists on showing you every minute or so, something new you can try with your echo show. Try x, y, or z. This is incredibly irritating after awhile, especially, if you are not particularly interested... AND THIS CANNOT BE TURNED OFF according to Amazon support. For a supposedly "customer centric company", very bad behavior. Force your customers to watch a commercial on the device they have purchased every minute or so.

The only way I have found to turn this off is to tell the device to "turn off the display". This works until something alerts it and it comes back on again, and the "try x, y or z" begins again.

However, you can train your self to ignore these messages, and eventually the home screen will time out, showing only a grey background with the time.

The device does so many things well, or reasonably well, I could not give it less than 4* even with this irritating behavior.

Review update: This thing has grown on me with use. Rating change 4* - > 5*.

Seems to be a very well made quality item. Functions well, particularly with Ring camera system. Can look through any camera by voice command.

Pandora music displays album cover, and progress bar. A CD without having to take care of the CD.

Fidelity is good, but better if tied to quality sound bar via blutooth.

Can view email by saying "open google", then selecting gmail or news or whatever from the google menu. Can respond to email, but difficult to forward to third parties, this needs improvement.

Very pleased with the device... have even trained myself to ignore the small print suggestions on the home screen that cannot be turned off. Occasionally, prompts me to try something interesting.

Thank you, Jeff. Nice product.

i got a great deal on amazon prime day. this is a gift to me!

it looks good and sounds real good. it was a seamless transition from an echo dot. i moved the dot to my upstairs hallway. This is a perfect upgrade. my family likes this device too.

i love the sound of the speakers. i played some songs using amazon music, and the screen showed me the words of the song while it played. i really like that.

i can open and close my nexx garage door opener and turn on and off alexa enabled switches throughout the house. i am slowly converting to an alexa ecosystem...

the setup was scary easy. it detected my amazon account and my wifi network. (that concerned me and scary me) there were some simple follow on instructions to setup the show.

i am still trying to get the hang of alexa skills... with that said, i hoped the show can give me the ability to see my skybell doorbell video, but nope. the doorbell is registered with alexa, but you can't see the freakin video. i also hoped i could see my nursery cam (cocoon cam), but nope... i still have to use my phone to see the nursery. i really hope they enable these features.

i left my stars as five, because overall this thing is awesome. if you can get it; get it. you won't be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glad I got it on sale, I'm disappointed.
reviews.reviewText: I, like many other reviewers, bought this because I work at home and wanted a hands-free entertainment device so I'm not delayed from things. The video streaming commands are beyond frustrating. I constantly have it not play things I'm requesting. It won't pause by verbal command. When you do pause it, if you have to do something longer than 2 minutes it closes the entire program and you have to find the episode you were watching again. Alexa's voice is insanely loud and I can't adjust it... so after my son goes to bed I can't use it because it's so loud I don't want to wake him up since my office is right off his bedroom. I constantly have issues with the touch screen not doing what I'm telling it to do (such as pressing play). Disappointed to say the least since I love my Echo and thought by the second generation kinks like this would be worked out.

reviews.reviewTitle: I wanted to be happy about this product, but...
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted to be happy about this product and for the first couple of weeks I was. For the past few weeks it either gives me the wrong information, videos abruptly stop and it reverts back to the home screen saver, things that worked before on it don't now, or it will abruptly talk at least once almost every hour.
I'm gonna start with the creepiest one, the fact that it talks. Once an hour, usually at night it will wake up and either say sorry I don't understand or something else without anyone near. We've had to unplug it at night so we won't get woken up.
Secondly, videos just stop playing and it reverts back to the home screen. This is super annoying when I'm trying out a new recipe or trying to entertain my little one for a minute while I take care of dishes or something else.
Next, I had synced my ring doorbell and nest cams up with it in the beginning and now it refuses to bring up video from either of them.
And lastly, it is a pain trying to bring up anything because either the wrong thing is opened or it'll constantly say "Sorry I don't understand" or "I didn't hear that."
To be sure that it's the device and not software, I had checked for updates, restored to factory defaults, and even unplugged the thing for hours hoping that any of those would fix it. Nothing works!!! It is so frustrating. If you get this device, please spring for the warranty because now I am out of the window for returning/replacing it, so I essentially have a large cumbersome paperweight.

reviews.reviewTitle: DON'T BUY for search or Youtube. BUY for sound and screen.
reviews.reviewText:
Cons:
- Youtube has to be played through the browser and you cannot voice search. So basically YOUTUBE IS NOT HANDSFREE.
-SEARCH IS NOT GOOD AT ALL. It will say, "I don't understand" if you ask for scores, or who has won in a sports game, or if you ask about world events, general questions about products, or productivity and all. The exact same questions get perfect 10/10 responses by Google home. Google's machine learning research is at least 10 years ahead of Amazon's. DO NOT buy this if you're looking for an assistant to answer everyday questions and assist you with work.
-It has 2 browsers but you cannot play Netflix through either one of them. So you CAN'T USE THIS FOR NETFLIX.

Pros:
-Great Sound quality
-Big screen
-Amazon Prime Video
-Good voice recognition
-Lot of skills for Alexa
-Good price
-Drop-in feature will let you check in on your dog!

reviews.reviewTitle: Screen times out if camera eye is covered
reviews.reviewText:
Why one star when I like so much? I covered the camera eye with duct tape because we are uncomfortable with potentially being watched by Amazon techs. The dreadful side affect is that the screen goes into screensaver mode after about 60 seconds because it cannot detect movement. And there is NO MANUAL WAY to prevent that from happening. You read that right. You have no option to prevent YOUR screen, on YOUR device, from doing what YOU want it to do.

It is absolutely, totally inexcusable to not offer the owner of any Alexa smart device with video control over there own screens. Wanna read the lyrics of your favorite song while on the elliptical? Forget about it.

If in a future update, screen control is turned back over to me, I give it 4.5 stars. As it is, you may as well buy a Dot.

reviews.reviewTitle: We caved. First Alexa specific product. Love it!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been curious about these Echo products for a few years but we waited, hoping to let Amazon work out some of the security kinks first. I came across a great cyber Monday sale and so we decided to give it a try. I wanted this one specifically for my kitchen, for recipes and videos. I read up a lot on it in advance, how to speak to it etc. There is a definitely some training on both sides. I approached it with patience as I figured out the right way to ask it do what I wanted. My husband (who normally hates technology) quickly took to it and loved it.

It has a long way to go yet as far as being a bit more intuitive. There are moments I'm glad it has a screen, when it gets befuddled over "return to the song" (or something silly) I can just walk over and tap the screen to get what I want. Sometimes it trips over itself. But, I can have my hands in the oven and baking and ask "Alexa, set timer for 6 minutes" (you can set multiple timers with different names - whaaaat?) while I'm watching some random tv show or news, or listening to music. "Alexa, how many tablespoons are in a half cup" or "...set a reminder pick up my prescription", "add garlic to my shopping list" "what's on my to do list for tomorrow?" Catch my drift? I really have found it super handy. I also listen to MORE music. I pay for Amazon music subscription but really only listened on my phone at the gym etc. Now on a whim, I find I come home from work and ask "Alexa, play radiohead" or something random while I'm taking off my coat, and voila! The quicker/easier access to music makes me utilize the service so much more.

I'm still a bit wary of the security, so I've left some things out. I didn't connect my contact list, as I wouldn't want an accidental call to go out to someone while we're having too many glasses of wine at 11pm. No one needs that. The drop in thing is no-go for me. I locked down as much as I could on that stuff. I like that there is a mute button I can press when I don't want her to listen, but we haven't used that as much as we thought we would. I've used it when talking "about her" to someone else on the phone (she kept piping into the conversation with her confusion, LOL. MUTE it Alexa.)

There's also a ton I still haven't tried. I haven't done any shopping on it. I haven't used it for smart home items. I haven't even used the Skype. And I STILL use it constantly and feel like its been impactful in our home.

All in all, a few gaps to work around so not nearly seamless, but otherwise, it's truly changed our kitchen experience for the better. So many neat little features. I rated it 5 stars based on how awesome this technology is and how great it is at some of these features. I was tempted to go 4 because it has so much further to go, but that didn't seem fair. It's a new technology. I grew up in a world before cell phones - so when I compare that and consider how far this has all come? 5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Still needs A Lot of Work
reviews.reviewText:
If you have more than 1 person in your house, this is probably not for you. I tried setting up an Echo Show for my Teen Daughter. I thought it would be nice for her to have reminders on it, her alarm, I can "drop in" to make sure she's up... etc etc. One problem. Can't setup an Echo with An Amazon Teen Account. It must be an adult account. So, If I set it up with my account... she can see all of my purchases, things on my to do list, she can add to my todo list, add and remove MY reminders.

Also, there is no way for Alexa to truly recognize the voices like SIRI does.

If I lived alone, I guess Alexa would make a great companion to have around.... but as she stands now... not so much. Oh... yeah... and if you are watching a television show or movie with a character named Alexa.... your Echo will answer. Let's just hope a television writer doesn't have a great sense of humor and work the phrase "Alexa, buy 100 pair of socks"

reviews.reviewTitle: What are you really going to use this for?
reviews.reviewText:
There is a delay in audio from my iPad to the Echo Show via Bluetooth so when I play video on the iPad, the sound from the Echo Show doesn’t sync with the video. I didn’t have this problem on the original Echo Show. The 2nd gen Echo Show screen is definitely larger and more vibrant.

Overall it’s not that useful unless you are going to watch something directly on it. It has Prime Video, Hulu and for some reason, NBC. Without Netflix, this makes it a light offering. The content (like news stories) it pushes out is rarely relevant to me. If you like following cooking recipes on tv, then this is probably good for the kitchen.

Alexa has all the same problems she has on every other Echo device, most frustratingly she can barely answer questions about what the device can do. Instead she either refers you to a help section that mysteriously isn’t available on the device itself even though it has a screen or she just says something like, “Hm, I don’t know that.” One improvement on Alexa’s shopping skills, particular to this device, is that you can look at the products, though it’s a narrow set.

I had the Echo Show Gen 1. We liked it and when there was a great deal on Prime day we jumped at the upgrade. I have liked the bigger screen and the sound quality is great (huge upgrade from gen 1). We have however had issues with this gen 2. It goes to sleep (shows time only) when we are in the room. We will talk to it and it will wake up respond and go back to sleep. Unplug/replug and then there is no audio. The only resolution for no audio has been to remove the plug from the back of the Echo Show, unplugging from the wall will not fix the issue. This has happened twice since our prime day purchase. Wondering if typical behavior or if we have a bad unit.

The "Drop-In" feature takes too long to connect and has strange feedback (for the first few seconds after connected); video takes a long time to show (dropping in on devices in my home).

Other annoyances are the "Try" messages that cycle through the home screen (on my Fire TVs as well).

STOP! DO NOT BUY!!
Look at the forums. Sound does not come on after it has been unplugged, even if it is unpaired to another device, even if you reset to factory settings, even if you unplug it repeatedly. AND THEY KNOW ABOUT THIS PROBLEM. My guess: They are unloading these things hoping a certain percentage of people will just pair them to a bluetooth speaker (which, richly enough, most people will buy from Amazon) & they'll still make a profit. I bought a couple of these, one for my elderly parents (because, after all, Amazon advertises how good this is for old people). Dealing with this issue would take a year off their lives. They'll be devastated not to get the drop ins to the grandkids. How can they advertise this as a device for old people? Why didn't I check the product forums first? DON'T MAKE MY MISTAKE! READ THE FORUMS.

The device itself works fine, as expected. The sound quality seems very good so far. Not as versatile as the fire I am replacing but the show is much better integrated with Alexa than the fire, which is what I bought it for, more compact too.
Why the single star? Amazon stole my WiFi password! When I plugged in my brand new show it connected right up without ever asking for my password and they're is no place in the phone so setup to enter or change it. They either have it stored somewhere on their cloud or it gets the password from one of the other devices on my network. Either way this seriously compromises the security of my network, which I take very seriously. So far as I know this is not mentioned in their privacy policy. So if you use Alexa and every hear that an Amazon database has been violated disconnect all Alexa devices and change your WiFi password, in that order.
UPDATE: I got a message from technical support that said that, yes, Alexa does store passwords in the cloud but that this can be disabled. The fact that this is enabled by default and that the question doesn't come up during setup makes this option pretty thin protection. Shades of Facebook!

reviews.reviewTitle: NOT WORTH YOUR MONEY. Limitations abound.
reviews.reviewText:
Just terrible. The Echo Show is so limited. Could be great in a few years but I’m not willing to wait because it’s TERRIBLE RIGHT NOW. Let’s start with what it CANNOT do.
Can’t play: YouTube or Netflix.
Doesn’t search: you can ask it questions but it won’t know 90% of them AND it won’t search it on bing. So the ad that Amazon shows saying “Alexa show me a recipe” is FALSE. You can’t manually type in searches either.

Partial capabilities: Searching, some apps let you search. Let’s start with Hulu. You can bring up Hulu but won’t have the option from the home screen to search on Hulu. You’ll have to find the right verbal request that’ll allow you to drag the endless screen for what you want. Example: I wanted to watch the current season of South Park.
Me: “Alexa play South Park season 22 episode 1.”
Alexa: “here is South Park season 1 episode 1.”
This happened every time! I had to have it bring up the South Park page then scroll to the episode I wanted. 22 seasons of scrolling took so long!
Let’s talk about the touch screen! THE NON RESPONSIVE TOUCH SCREEN! I practically had to punch the thing to get it to react to my haptics. Am I supposed to double PUSH to get a video to play? Or pause? Don’t even try to drag the progress bar to rewind advance an episode or song, just accept your fate and play from where you’re at or start over.
I can complain about so many more first world problems here, but it’s not worth my time or yours. Pass on this and get a tablet.

I'm being a little favorable and grading this on a curve with credit for the potential that it has. If I could I'd give it a 4.5 stars (4 stars for today, .5 stars because it has load of potential.

Display: Excellent. It's big and I felt it was going to be too awkward at first because of the size but once I started using it the size of the display (and the unit) were more spot on.

Interface: Good, customizable. Scrolls information if you want and adjusts based on lighting and activity around it (i.e. turns off/dims when dark and not active). Can control quite a few things including lights from the interface and also does a great job with video and other media both with displays and control. Alexa works well in displaying information in usable forms (lists, links, data, video clips, etc). While I can control lighting, I found Google Home hub has a better interface for controlling things; just easier to get to and very easy/quick to turn on and off things in the same room. I have not used any of the video calling etc. but from what I've seen that's pretty solid.

Sound: This thing sound great. Full sound. Not going to replace any high end systems for music or movies but it's good. I tend to use it for audiobooks when I'm doing work around the house moreso than anything else and it's great for that.

Amazon still hasn't integrated things like Ring into this as well as is should. As a comparison, the Google Home Hub integrates excellent with Nest. Someone ring the nest doorbell and it immediately shows the camera, it very quick with accessing other cameras or the thermostat. I think it will get there and when it does it potentially will be better as I think the hardware is better (faster, better display, etc).

Like the concept, but for me, its just another echo at a higher price. I have 3 echos, 6 Dots and a tap so I have experience with these products, but still find this one awkward to use. When you play a song, lyrics scroll. So if you like karaoke at hope, you'll like this. The connectivity with blink cameras (the reason I purchased) is underwhelming. I expected to see all 10 of my cameras on the screen, get alerts etc. Instead, no alerts and I have to ask for which camera I want to see, remembering all 10 names. So once I get an alert on my phone, I can then use the device to ask to see a live feed. I might just be an Alexa eShow dummy, but I liken this to my short lived Google Glass experience.

reviews.reviewTitle: "Sorry, I'm not sure about that" get used to hearing that.
reviews.reviewText: I am so angry with Amazon/Jeff bozo Bezos that I am giving this one star. No other recourse. Amazon, in its finite wisdom, chose to not allow me to watch netflix or any other source of my choosing on this device. It's mine and I paid for it but just like most leftists with power I can only watch what they want me to watch. My wife purchased this thing but had I known I could only watch what Amazon wanted me to I would have sent it back. Get used to the phrase "sorry, I'm not sure about that" cause this thing doesn't know what end is up most of the time. Siri blows this thing out of the water and siri tech is older. These things cost too much to be limited. Just imagine you purchase a cell phone but the maker wouldn't allow you to access google. This is NO DIFFERENT!

For the $229 price tag I thought it should do more. I bought the Alexa Show so that my kids could communicate with others and myself while at home, for access to Hulu and a fun tech item. I have been able to communicate to my wife but others have not been as intuitive. I know my son tried calling me yesterday and it nothing came through even though I was on the phone. I'm going to have to play with it to figure it out. I just wished it was more intuitive. Hulu does work and it is not to have on in the kitchen where we have placed the Amazon Show. But you have to ask for specific shows. There is no way to surf your account or pick a specific episode. I wish I had some navigation capability. I also wished it had some YouTube functionality. I realize that it is owned by a competitor but there could at least be some internet functionality that would allow you to access it online. I also wished it had the ability to connect with my Pinterest account. I use Pinterest with a lot of recipes and I would enjoy having it on my Amazon Show.
Overall, the Amazon show is nice to have but it lacks a lot of the functionality that we are used to with out phones and tablets. It does sound great and I do like the bass balance. I know my kids love asking it to play their favorite songs from Amazon music.

reviews.reviewTitle: Eco Show is a Must Have
reviews.reviewText: The Eco Show is a great product and a lot of fun to have around the house. If you have an Amazon Eco or Eco Dot, the Eco Show is a must have! The Eco Show is compatible with both the Eco and Eco Dot and the Show is very easy to set up, it’s almost completely ready out of the box! And the sound from the Eco Show is awesome! You can adjust bass, treble, etc. The screen is huge and very clear. I don’t watch movies on my Eco Show, but one could and it would be a great devise to do that on. I have my Eco Show, Eco and Eco Dot synced up so I can hear my Amazon music all through my apartment!! It sounds awesome! The cost of the Eco Show is reasonable! There’s not enough room on this review to tell you what all the Eco Show does. I would recommend if you’re thinking of purchasing one to go on UTube, they’re several reviews on there that gives you a great idea as to what the Eco Show can do. I can tell you that all the reviews are positive! Mine was a Birthday gift from my family and I love it!!

First off I'll say that I like my echo devices for the most part. I was given a "TAP" as a gift and that was awesome. It's a bluetooth speaker and an ECHO device. I've since purchased 2 DOTS, a ECHO, and ECHO SHOW for my 88 year old father, which led me to get one for myself after not being able to video chat with him using Skype on my IPAD. I was excited to get it and to call him, but there was no audio. Amazon support did their job but it wasted a day, and I feel like they should have offered a replacement after the first tech chat session. I reset the device to factory, checked for software update and still nothing. They said they would check with their resources.....I left for work,. Upon returning home I tried again and nothing, so I chatted and tried to change the EQ and enable voice screen and they then told me they would request a replacement. They should have done that from the start. I hope the replacement works.

reviews.reviewTitle: Forced advertisements, Not better than echo I already have
reviews.reviewText:
Terrible constant advertisements, won’t turn off advertisements, got wyze bundle for baby cam, cam shows only for short time then returns to useless advertisements, unable to get movement or sound alerts or move cam to see parts of room, terrible flashing advertisements all night long keep me awake when there is no emergency big boomy bass sound, can’t tell if any Dolby or quality sound processing is even present, really!? I can’t believe with all the sound engineers in the world this would come out. I am planning to return and wait for much better model. I would keep if I could turn off advertisements and keep baby cam on constantly as I can always ask for weather time and news updates. I am surprised it does not even offer me my amazon wish list adverts or senior with bad eyesight sized time and weather options for images to be easily voice customized or free tickets to a local event or that my amazon packages have been delivered or my returns must be sent by date soon. Somebody wake up and make it useful instead of pushing sales advertisements that make me wish for another remote control just to mute the unrelated useless visuals. I have one echo to control my sonos and three iOS to see wyze cams. I am sorry to say that voice control over basic wyze app function and basic customizable echo show functions are not available. I also wrote in email customer service in Alexa app to complain about shows inabilities and no response at all. I get perfect customer service about all other buys and returns but why not customizing the amazon echo
Show itself? Surprise surprise! Well how many upgrades to go until really useful? I need to care for another life now and I can’t wait. For all the time and years on amazon they can’t instantly make useful content available to me? I also expected amazon to compete with apple speaker and sonos speaker but no surround sound processing and at least the bass is booming. I am looking forward to new models and I enjoy most all other parts of amazon ecosystem.

Sound was on and off for first month. Then, after return period expired, no sound at all. went through diagnostics and resetting to factory settings. no sound. Attached external Bluetooth earphones and heard sound. Ergo, the show internal speaker connection is defective. Turns out this is a known quality issue, widely written about.
I called customer service and they insisted I send back the unit for warranty inspection before they would send out a replacement and was told I would receive a replacement within 5 business days. That was a week ago and no communication so far. My order list says that it was submitted to a repair vendor who will repair and return it in 10 business day. They should have sent out a replacement with overnight shipping to replace the faulty device and then asked me to send back the defective one in the box with a prepaid shipping label.

Here is my only complaint...which Amazon cannot apparently fix, or at least they won't tell me how to fix it....If you have subscribed calendars. they will not show up or be recognized by the device--despite being clearly listed on the app as supposed to be listed. By way of example, I subscribe to a couple of sports teams calendars linked to my apple calendar. These show up on my apple calendar. These subscriptions also show up on the Alexa app (so it does know they are there), and are checked to be included on the device...yet they are not. Called about it was told it was being sent up (as they also told me with a FireTv issue) and that I would hear back in 2-4 days. As with the still unresolved FireTV issue I never hear back from anyone and so now I have two unresolved issues.

Normally I would not care but I do a lot of umpiring and all of my assignments come through Arbiter (probably has no meaning to most reading). But I am subscribed to an Arbiter calendar that automatically puts these events on our family apple calendar. I purchased this so the family could see when I had games. But again, this does not work--despite the calendar being checked in Alexa to be included on the device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much larger and better than the original
reviews.reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised how much larger this one was over the original Show. The screen display is also much better. The sound quality is also great. I'm glad I decided to purchase the newest version.

After reading some online reviews, I decided to update mine. First, this isn't my first device. We have one in every room (echo, dot, show - 1st gen, & spot). Second, the more you use it, the better the experience and the better it is for Alexa to understand what you want. Third, once I figured out how to set up groups and connect all devices, the experience increased significantly. I can play music in any combination of rooms in my home from my cell phone app. It's been entertaining randomly starting funny songs on the bathroom dot when my unsuspecting husband is hanging out in there too long! Fourth, I work from my home office and have my spot on the office desk. Once I synced my calendar, it was a game changer! I can see upcoming meetings from anywhere I have a screen or just ask the non-screen devices what's on my schedule. I LOVE this feature!

Finally, having 3 adult children, I bought all of them a 1st gen show, now we can do video calls to each other from different sides of the country at any time since this works both on the screen device and on your cell phone. This is wonderful and my favorite feature.

Doesn't have any sort of home screens, no apps. Nothing like a tablet and nearly useless. Cannot preform searches. I get real tired of hearing alexa say "sorry, i don't know that". Amazon has purposely blocked things like netflix, even through the browser. This thing should be able to do everything the fire tv can... you cant even shop on amazon with it normally. you get some weirdly watered down version of everything. My $50 fire tablet is far superior to this $250 POS. Not worth the money. The Echo plus seems to understand commands better and do more things. NOT AT ALL what you'd expect from an amazon device. Regretfully purchased.

Oh. My. Goodness! I have the original echo show and kep talking myself out of upgrading. So so glad I finally chose to get the 2nd gen echo show! Superior in every way, including of course the larger screen and better sound. Various features are improved as well - like reminders. I put the old show in the kitchen, where, it turns out, everyone in the household uses it!

This new show is on a table that sits along the side of my bed. The angle is perfect for lying on my side to watch you tube videos or prime videos when i go to bed. The screen size is excellent for that purpose, and for reading lyrics. The old show screen was hard on my old eyes. The sound is much improved as well.

The only thing I wish for (and this applies to both generations) is that there were more skills made specifically for the show, and that they were easier to find. Most wanted? A calendar that displays on the screen, and maps, including local. Without using the browser.

All in all, I love the 2nd gen echo show and highly recommend it.

Right out of box we have no sound what so ever. I have read where Amazon tells people to rest and so on but it ends up being a temp fix. Guess we will have to send it right back. What a let down......

reviews.reviewTitle: Something is missing for the price
reviews.reviewText:
Edit 1/11/2018. I stick with my 2-star rating but this is relative to the 10" Fire tablet and price. The Show 2 is not bad and I get it that there are niche uses. Unfortunately, those niches are not for me. IMHO the Show should run Android and not this experimental and buggy funny interface. Even if I liked this funny interface, it is also available on the tablet. I like an Echo Dot with a screen (=Echo Spot). Amongst others I can travel with it and easily change the WiFi. Can I travel with the Show? Possibly but ...

It does, what it does and it is not bad except that the current software has issues. I cannot play Prime movies. Sound is worse than my $50 bluetooth soundbar. Screen is just 720p. Why, please why does this thing even exist? I mean, for that price Amazon could have taken the 10" Amazon Fire tablet hardware and pug into the speakers of the Show. And please: what is Amazon thinking? Another proprietary power plug? How about USB C?

No, the Show is not bad. It just misses the point (for me).

reviews.reviewTitle: What a RIP-OFF for the price
reviews.reviewText: I was so excited about getting one of these. A family member has one and I LOVED it. Granted they paid half the price I did but, if it did the same and worked then the price would be worth it. IT DID NOT live up to the hype and the price was not worth trying to figure out why it did not recognize my commands. Even the HELP center couldn't figure it out and just gave me a free return label. Great now I have to look elsewhere for a better product. It seem to be fine with the installing and pairing but every time I asked for something NOTHING. YES I am tech savvy and followed all the prompts still nothing! Another tidbit they don't disclose is you need a subscription to AMAZON prime for movies, TV, music. No other services can be used (i.e. NETFLIX, HULU, ITUNES MUSIC etc.) that is a BIG requirement to leave off the description. I expect a full refund. I have been an AMAZON shopper for years and this is the biggest disappointment I have had and the price was way beyond what it is worth.

We've been using these for about 2 months now. I was worried about them not being loud enough but they are and the sound is pretty great. It looks good and love that we can put our own picture on it as the homepage. I love that it engages you throughout the day by adding interesting facts and new stories that show up on the screen. However I have to remove a star for the same reason. Let's say that Alexa shows a fantastical story about a huge banana someone has sculpted and it made headlines all over the world. When you ask her to tell you about it, she reads the story but there is no true picture of the object in question. Instead, you get to see a regular banana instead. The name is Echo SHOW. Please show me what you are talking about. The video quality is pretty good when talking to others in different rooms and the recognition of voices is better than other Echo units. For instance, the Echo Show in the basement will sometimes answer me at the same time as the Echo show upstairs. I think I'm going to purchase another one but I hope that the stories get a little more, "showy".

reviews.reviewTitle: "Things to Try" needs to be turned off. Google Nest Home Hub beats Echo Show in features and quality
reviews.reviewText:
I bought a Google Nest Home Hub and an Echo Show to compare which is a better picture frame and home hub. While I use Amazon Echo for all my smart speakers, the Google Nest Home Hub is the better assistant with a display. The Echo Show has a larger screen, but the picture quality is lower than the Google display. For the digital picture frame feature, Google has Echo beat with a much better presentation - Google's display stays in picture frame mode by default and can show two portrait images side-by-side. The Echo show doesn't even shuffle the images on the home screen, which is baffling! The biggest thing is that you can't turn off the "Try this" prompts! This makes the Echo Show fail as a photo frame.

This would be a 4-5 star product if Amazon enabled Home screen photo frame shuffling and allowed you to remove the "Try this" prompts. For a better photo frame, get a Google Nest Home Hub.

Bought this with great excitement to be able to play prime movies while in the kitchen. Sadly this Alexa is very hard of hearing. Some commands went unnoticed. The worst was trying to get it to play Prime Movies. That's right Amazon's device could not play movies from it's own streaming service without us wanting to pull our hair out. Most of the time she ignored play commands, other times the movies would just never start even though she showed the movie, and said she would play it. 1 star is to generous.

Just spent 50 minutes with foreign speaking people...had to ask for supervisor who still did not understand what I needed. I have 1st generation which allows me to play slide show continuously. This does not have this feature. After close to 1 HR, they said this does not have this feature & this input would be submitted to technicians to make update...no promises WHEN this would happen. I asked to exchange this one for older version which works fine...I have only had this 1 week & have struggled with speaker groups, music volume going up & down, interruptions by Pandora, or just music stopping... EVERYTHING IS WRONG WITH THIS 2ND GENERATION!
Nothing made me happier than having an Amazon "technician supervisor" telling me, "Mam, you are right" to a 75 yr/old!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: All functions seem to work but the sound. NO SOUND
reviews.reviewText: Absolute Garbage. Worked for 1 hour then sound no longer worked. Called help center but they could not do anything to fix it. Huge waste of money for something that does not live up to its hype. Really expected more from Amazon. Sending it back. Will look into google home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Considering returning this thing due to Bluetooth problems
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this to replace an old school Echo speaker only. I use that via bluetooth to play audio from a Microsoft Windows Surface device, audio that comes from a special server accessible by a browser like Chrome. The old Echo speaker worked perfectly. I wanted 2 more things, first, a slideshow of my Amazon photos, and second, a self-dimming clock. Both those functions worked splendidly except...

When streaming Bluetooth, the Echo Show would frequently just flat out stop working. No audio. Or after about an hour, the audio over the Bluetooth would become fuzzy and distorted and broken. If I turned off the Windows device, the Echo Show still thought it was connected! I had to restart the Show and repair the thing to my Windows device.

While playing the audio, it would constantly show me "Now Playing", which interrupted the slideshow and clock entirely! No way of turning that off that I could find. And worse the Show would randomly connect and disconnect with the Windows over Bluetooth. USELESS TO ME IN THIS STATE! I wanted the better audio from this to play while it just kept displaying my photos and appointments on the home screen, but no, it kept switching over to NOW PLAYING. What an awful thing.

I've been using my Echo Speaker Only for two or more years without problem! I wish this Show would achieve the level of connectivity and reliability. I now have my old Echo Speaker, with the microphone muted, sitting next to the show so I can play my audio AND display my photos and appointments and clock continuously.

It's unacceptable to have two of these things next to each other! Worse yet, if you have multiple Echo devices within earshot of each other, and I mean one or two rooms away, when you say Alexa, they all wake up and dogpile each other and it's a crapshoot which device will actually process your command, like "Alexa, what time is it".

They should allow you to set ANY WORD as a WAKE WORD so that you can address each one separately and uniquely. Furthermore, when one device (wake word Alexa) announces that you have an AMAZON shipment, another device nearby with the wake word of AMAZON will wake up and almost attempt to reorder the item.

This smart speaker world is fraught with frustrating pitfalls especially when one of them THINKS it hears it's name, or an Amazon Alexa advertisement is playing on the TV and they all wake up stupidly.

PLEASE FIX THIS. Getting rid of these rough edges, and it would be a pleasure to have them around.

reviews.reviewTitle: 🎶🎵🎶 It's all about that bass, bout that bass, bout that bass ~ and bringin' booty back 🎶🎵🎶
reviews.reviewText:
👸My house is, and will probably forever be, owned by Alexa!👸
First, let me say, that I bought the Echo 2nd Generation, and the Google Hub at the very same time, just to try them both out. And boy, I could not send that Google Hub back to where it came from fast enough! It may be great for smart home only users, but it is no fun or really that useful, other than that, at all! You cannot even get answers or videos that come even close to what Google gives you on your cell phone!! And, it is not for the sight impaired- meaning me. If I needed to know the time after 6pm, I asked Alexa. I don't get it...
And, oh yeah baby! I love lyric mode on this thing! This bad boy can rock your booty off, for sure! The bass vibrates everything on my kitchen counter! I love it!!
I call mine Alexxx sometimes... it answers, most of the time, no matter which name- Alexa or Alexxx. I do wish it had a man's voice, sometimes.... really could use hearing one once in a while! It's kinda funny, sometimes, I just get ignored- similar to a man lol. Like, when I asked her to repeat the same song for the tenth time. Or, she will just decide that I need to listen to a certain playlist, instead of said song. It's annoying, but sometimes the first song is so good, it gets me to listen. Still... If I say play this song, and she says, I'll play "this" instead, it's rude!
Another thing I absolutely love, is watching YouTube. I've saved my Channel to the homepage in the Silk Browser, so all I have to do is just tell it to open YouTube. It goes straight to my homepage. I can go to or watch my subscription feed and playlists, go to my watched history, watch recommended videos, and easily search for anything I would like to watch. It is so quick and easy to navigate! My most favorite thing to watch, is Criminal trials, and they last for weeks. So, while I'm working in the kitchen doing other things, or just sitting around the table, I can pick up where I left off on my Fire Stick, and watch them right there on my echo.
I can search the internet for anything! I can type it in, or make it even faster by using my voice and just hitting the enter key on the onscreen keyboard.
I've heard a lot of people complain that there are too many steps to do things on the Echo. But, I can get to anywhere on mine almost as quickly as I can on my regular computer.
I hate to say that I haven't ventured out into the many, many things this thing can do, other than these few things, but they're the ones that I enjoy. One day, I'll try venturing out into unchartered territory for myself on this lovely device.
I know I can tell you one thing is for certain. I will definitely be buying more of these wonderful, booty shaking, singing to the top of my lungs, mind blowing gadgets very soon! I just have to have them in several rooms! I highly, highly, highly recommend the Echo 2nd Generation to everyone! REALLY, EVERYONE!!

We have a Google mini but wanted to upgrade to a smart device with a video screen. We selected the Echo Show 2 because the reviews said the sound was superior to the comparable Google device and because the built-in camera allowed video conferencing - something we do regularly. While the speakers and picture lived up to our expectations, the quality of Skype calls was poor. And, my wife was never able to get it to connect properly to her calendar.

Most importantly, Alexa did not give correct responses to many simple questions, including follow up questions to the trending topics that were suggested that we ask Alexa. Just 2 examples of many, Alexa suggested we ask about: A rare chimera cardinal, but it was unable to respond correctly when we asked to see pictures. And, Usain Bolt beating the NFL 40-yard dash record, but it could not respond correctly when we asked what was the record time. Also, it was unable to respond correctly on multiple occasions when we wanted to see recipes for specific foods.

Every day we experienced numerous instances where Alexa could not provide an answer, but we were able to get the correct answer from the Google Assistant. (The requests for pictures was done with our smart phones but others were done with the Google Mini.) The inability to respond and/or the incorrect responses from the onset caused us to start testing and comparing Alexa versus the Google Assistant right away. After a week, we had enough and concluded that Alexa was unable to meet our needs.

Because of our extreme frustration with getting accurate information, we never bothered to connect Alexa to the other smart devices in our home, so we cannot say how Alexa might have handled tasks like turning lights on and off. And, I was not satisfied with the limited selection offered to shopping inquiries versus the selection offered when looking at Amazon on my computer.

While the reviews indicated that Alexa is compatible with more 3rd party devices, they also said that Google had the edge to answering informational inquiries. We just never imagined that the discrepancy would be so great. If getting answers to questions regarding news, sports or 'how to' are important, we suggest you go with the Google Assistant.

The final irony came as I prepared to return the product. Alexa was unable to respond to the question of how to reset the device to the factory defaults, but Google was able to give me the answer.

reviews.reviewTitle: AMZ is getting much closer with the Gen2 Show, a good upgrade!
reviews.reviewText:
THIS is the product that SHOULD have been the Gen1 release and every feature (of the guts) was available and affordable to make, so I wanted to get that criticism out of the way straight up.

Now the goods and bads, mixed by feature.

Come for the sound? Stay for the display.
The reality is that this is NOT HD, but ED, 720p for video playback. HD is 1080p for video playback. If UHD can be built into cellphones, not even phablets, then the raw displays and drivers are clearly MUCH cheaper as they increase in size. Still, this is a much better, approximately twice as large display than the Gen1 Show's display, though it doesn't seem to be any brighter, something I've seen lab-tested to be so. Since this is not OLED, it's not going to do better in your sun-drenched kitchen than the Gen1 did, even if it is clearer and larger so you can see it more easily on the other side of your island.

But what really disappointed people most in the Gen1 Show was the sound. Not that it was bad... it just wasn't good. I have $30 portable radios that blow it away. The recently upgraded software for Spot/Show helps GREATLY by finally providing individual bass/mid/treble controls which most people will set wrong. And while the bass and "whomp" is MUCH better from the new Gen2 Show, it's typical big passive radiator v tiny active driver sound. Flabby and prone to splat, even at moderate volume (maybe halfway up with a good sounding recording like stuff from GRP). So, sure, it's able to play louder and it has more bass but it's not quality bass. If there was enough room for a huge passive radiator and the cavity(s) needed to make it function properly, there was room for an active bass driver with a smaller passive so it would be in much better control using a folded audio waveguide, if needed, perhaps even as a replacement for the passive. Most people can't hear that this isn't quite there but people who are accustomed to real audio, my career background serving audiophiles for decades, know better than to go for passives. But they're cheap, so I get it. Lots of bang for the buck... or whomp for the buck.

At lower volumes, though, it works and sitting on my desk in front of my second monitor, it couples will with the desk surface for bass I feel in my hands. I will experiment to see if this is a good thing or if decoupling is smarter. Also, this new larger Gen2 Show is actually SHORTER than the Gen1, so it is easier to put on a desk with other media equipment and still see behind it, key for me, even if it is much wider and deeper.

Please continue reading in my replies since AMZ doesn't like long reviews even when they are very detailed and warranted...

But the Show failed in just about every way. First, when you ask it to search for something, it usually brings up something totally unrelated (I asked it for a sous vide chicken recipe and it brought up the temperature in Chicken, Alaska - I didn't even know there was a Chicken, Alaska so I guess it taught me something!). I'm highly disappointed that this doesn't have a web browser - lots of issues there because it can't do much because of that. Beware if you're buying this for recipes as I did. There is NO "skill" that will allow you to enter your own recipes to view on the screen. Yes, you can download "Allrecipes" skill and "Food Network" but I've even tried searching for my favorite recipes on Food Network and this device does not bring up the recipes (ex. Alton Brown's refrigerator pie). Amazon has a long way to go before this Show device is actually usable.

reviews.reviewTitle: came free with my new samsung phone
reviews.reviewText: This came as a bonus on black friday with my phone. My son was away in the military and I thought we could use it to skype. If there are specific things you need echo for, be sure it 'does' it first. Had to go all around the mulberry bush to get that to work. On top of it, Amazon has discontinued its music/streaming service that allows you to upload YOUR music and listen to it, the main reason I even have echo (I have another one, not a show). I have thousands of songs, mostly local and odd live performances from festivals I film and local shows that are not available commercially, and why on earth should I PAY amazon for music I own? I talked to chat and they were no help and I will not longer recommend echo products as that's the main reason I use them. Otherwise, it's just an expensive turn on the tv paperweight!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Does Not Show Caller ID or Caller name on the Screen
reviews.reviewText:
If you hope to be able to visually monitor incoming telephone calls by using this in conjunction with an Echo Connect, forget about it. I have two Echo Show 2nd Generation units and two Echo Show 1st Generation units and none of them show od say who is calling either with a name or a telephone number. All the screen shows and a voice says is "Incoming Call" with no visual or audio indication as to who is calling. Apparently, these features used to work but they no longer work. The Echo Connect is also supposed to announce the caller information on Echo units that don't have a screen, but that doesn't work either. For more information see the Amazon Forum about this issue. It looks like Amazon Tech Support ahs dropped the ball on getting this fixed. I just spent an hour on the phone with Amazon Tech Support and it looks like they haven't done much or anything to solve this problem
Check out the bottom of page 2 and all of page 3 on this Amazon Forum to read complaints that started on October 31, 2018:
https://www.amazonforum.com/forums/devices/echo-alexa/476517-echo-connect-talking-caller-id-not-working?page=2

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo Show is very easy to use
reviews.reviewText:
Echo show lives up to its billing. Great unit. With some trepidation I bought Echo Show for my wife's 81st birthday.
Now the downside possibility was that she would not use it....she hates computers, hates anything mechanical, does not want any clutter on the kitchen counter tops. She doesn't even have an ATM card....I bought it two weeks early, set it up when she was out, found a place above the counter to place it and hoped for the best....she loves it (well at least likes it a lot)....she doesn't have to ask me about the weather, she has learned to do shopping list and to do list and she has at least looked at the receipes.....and all she has to do is say "Echo, Print" whatever it is and she has a hard copy.
Thanks for providing a great product!!!
Bought 2 of these. The sound doesn’t work on either one. I’ve walked through all troubleshooting w amazon and arranged for replacements. What a waste of time. I hope the new ones work.

I would give this device a much higher rating if the battle between Amazon and Google didn't interfere with it's operation. As it is the echo show is limited in capabilities such as not being able to play Netflix, browsing capabilities. Everything you search on google takes you to an Amazon page. So forget trying to buy something elsewhere. It's the customers who buy these devices who suffer. Pretty sad when you pay for something and are short changed because of a squabble between 2 corporations. Then there is the fact of learning to use it. A manual in the form of a downloadable pdf file would help immensely. Hopefully they will upgrade and improve this device so it is compatible with and will play well with services other than Amazon. Otherwise I would consider buying other devices. It has some nice features and the sound is good but it could be so much better. For that reason I feel Amazon is making a mistake in not bringing this product to it's full potential. People will buy Google Home Hub, Facebook Portal, Lenovo Smart Display and others if Amazon doesn't get wise.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mediocre echo device for what I wanted
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted a smart home assistant with a video display that showed me a feed of my smart cameras (specifically my Ring doorbell) and that functioned as a digital picture frame.
So the Amazon Echo Show does show me the feed of my Ring doorbell, but my expectations were the Echo Show to display the feed if someone rang the doorbell. It's a bit cumbersome needing to ask "Alexa" to show the camera IF you know that someone is at the door. Ideally, this functioned more like the Nest doorbell + Google home mini hub. It's kind of a head scratcher why this feature wasn't included as it's a pretty common use case people would expect to have.
My 2nd complaint is that it does not continuously cycle through my Amazon photos. After a while, it just stays on one photo. I've read that unplugging/plugging in the device would cycle through the photos again (or asking "Alexa" to play slideshow).
Knowing what I know now, I probably would have opted for a Nest doorbell to go with my Google home mini hub for my home video surveillance needs (although I would still be using the less expensive Echo devices since I prefer "Alexa" voice commands) and skipped purchasing this.
What I like about the device is that it's loud, bright, the on screen display for light controls and the rotating photo display (when it works).

I’ve got two echo shows first generation and one echo and when I saw this large screen echo second generation, I really wanted it. I liked the idea of the bigger screen because I occasionally will watch a movie on it. Other than that, it’s really not much different than the first generation. One of the things I do not like at all, is the amount of bass. I’ve turned the base all the way off and it still vibrates terribly. Enough that I almost want to take it back. As far as voice recognition, I often have to repeat things two or three times before it understands me. That can be very frustrating. At times it doesn’t hear me at all, and other times it gets the entire thing wrong. You just never know. But that’s no different than the generation one. I have gotten it to integrate with a few things in my house, but not as many as I would like. I will need to keep trying. Sometimes the directions are not easy to follow. I would like to have the same music in several of my rooms but have yet to be able to accomplish that. I do like the ability to keep adding to my shopping list by voice or to check my shopping list by voice and then pull up the shopping list on my phone while at the store. I use that quite frequently. It’s much more limited compared to Siri when trying to look something up. It will often say, I’m sorry, I’m not able to tell you that, etc. It is constantly updating the little stories that you can read or see a video but unfortunately, it usually doesn’t give you enough detail or kind of just leaves you hanging. I’m pretty much always disappointed with their little stories. I will keep investigating what else I can do on Echo, I’ve only had it a few weeks so I guess I need more time. If anything changes I will update this review.

This was a gift. So i hooked it up, ran it through the setup procedure, and.... no sound. "Alexa, tell me a joke". Joke shows up on the screen, but no sound. Called Amazon customer support, who advised that they are having a problem with Echo show 2nd gen. Asked me to wait until end of day to see if engineers come up with solution, but called back in an hour and asked me to send it back. So.... 1 star for sending out a product without adequately testing it, embarrassing me in the process.

I really do enjoy using this product in the mornings when I'm getting ready for my day. I just ask Alexa to either tune me into my favorite radio station to listen to my favorite DJs in the morning or I have her play some of the songs I have on file or I have her show me some of the films we have available on Prime Video. The only issue I have noticed so far is that on the one in my smaller bathroom (I purchased 2--one for the master and one for the smaller where I usually get ready) she (Alexa) does not respond properly when I ask her to stop playing or to pause or whatever it is I am asking her to do--she does not get the command correct until I typically shout it at her several times. I have gone to just straight up ignoring the voice commands and using the swipe mode instead!

First and foremost....the sound that comes from the Echo Show is AMAZING! I listen to it all, from Country to 90's rap.... The Beetles to Disturbed. I was blown away by the quality of the sound output. It makes cooking and cleaning more enjoyable and upbeat.

If music really isn't your thing, you should be impressed with the recipe finder and follower feature (I'm sure there is a legit name for this feature but "Recipe Finder and Follower" just rolls off the tongue so I'm sticking with it). The Echo Show pulls recipes from various websites, and doesn't just force you to follow some site that has paid extra fees to be featured. If you select your recipe, Alexa will even read it to you step by step.

My 11 year old loves the Echo Show because he can easily find videos he wants to share with me by simply saying "Alexa, find me a video of Ariana Grande doing impressions of other singers", etc.....and then selecting the right video. The device has also solved petty arguments such as "does green colored mucus mean you have an infection?". My 14 year old loves it because he can ask those hard to answer questions like "How much am I worth on the Black Market?" or "Why is my mom so bossy?".

The multitude of ways this device can make your life easier is amazing. The only con I have noticed so far is that sometimes I have to say "Alexa" repeatedly when it is playing music. That's more of an annoyance than a real problem unless you are listening to some raunchy rap or Bill Burr when your child walks in.

This device is by far the worst addition to the Echo family so far. The idea of a screen to communicate is shrouded with incessant messages, haptic feedback, miserable intelligence and overall inconvenience. You will be much better off buying a cheap iPad and using the Echo Dot so you can at least move it.

Ideas to improve for the next generation:
-IMPROVE THE TOUCH SCREEN
The screen is so unresponsive, I'd love to give up on it entirely. I have to press "buttons" on the screen five or more times for it to register. While I'd love to alleviate these woes with voice commands, the device is severely impaired and has selective hearing. Often times my commands won't even have a single understood word. As much as I'd like to tell my Echo Show to "stop giving me command options," it won't "know that."
-Display options
If I have to see one more "Try, Alexa, tell me something weird" prompt, I might throw up. You're a passive device, not my reluctant friend with ADD.
-Improved syncing:
While your speakers are marginally better than previous Echo devices, the connection between devices to have multi room music is awful. They are not in sync and it sounds collectively distorted and unpleasant to say the least.

Can I have my money back?

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved the multiple timers you could set while cooking. But not the glitches
reviews.reviewText: I actually returned this item, I could only watch select prime videos and select Hulu videos, it did not have my list available and from time to time Alexa would not set timers and respond properly when asked stuff on a few occasions I had to unplug the power cord and plug back in for her to be responsive. For sure has some work needed to be done and I’d suggest getting Netflix and directv now service on it. Would of been the perfect size for my kitchen for cooking and videos but did not work out for me at this time, I think it’s needing much improvement before I would consider buying it again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Limited use for a touch-screen Echo device
reviews.reviewText:
When I bought this during Amazon's "Prime Day", I was excited to give it a shot. I love my Echo devices and use them all the time. I figured this one would be a fine addition to my collection. By and large, it is, but there are a few things that led to the 3-star rating, which I will explain below.

First, sound quality and voice recognition on this thing are superb. Video quality is quite good too, though from my own eyes I would say most top end tablets have this thing beat handidly. This thing will hear you from wherever you are in your house, and you will hear it.

Now, the reason I didn't give it 5-stars is this: I don't see how truly more useful this thing is over my other Echo devices. Its limited functionality as a screen device is what brings it down for me. There is very, very limited "app" support (and good lulck trying to side-load anything). You're at the whim of the Amazon catalog, which basically limits your video options to Amazon Prime and Twitch - both of which are fabulously entertaining platforms, but still very limiting.

This device flourishes in a kitchen setting where you can view recipes and watch on-screen instructions, but the options there seem quite limited and not as versatile as just having a good cookbook by your side. Its a great device for music, but so are the other Echo devices. The option for on-screen lyrics is neat, but also useless in the grand scheme of things.

By and large, what makes this device great is also what makes it hard to review: its really meant for the kitchen. I tried it as a bedside table device, and it didn't really ad anything. Tried it as a living room device, but for what purpose? In the kitchen? That's where its meant to be. And that, combined with what I mentioned above, is its limiting factor.

We have several Alexa speakers and this is our first show. Overall we like the concept, and the sound quality is good but there are a few things about it that are frustrating. I don't know how anyone can give this thing 5 stars though, primarily for the main reason below that it's slow.

So about slow. I don't know how Amazon could ship this honestly in the state it's in. Drop in calls sometimes work fine and other times time out or take forever to connect. Same with skills. The Jeopardy skill regularly crashes back to the main screen and videos are slow to respond or become unresponsive for many 10s of seconds requiring me to manually cancel it or on rare occasion reboot the device. Honestly in this area it needs polish. I'd send it back if a replacement speaker wasn't the same price (I got it on a sale at a substantial discount).

As others have noted as well it would be nice to have some more flexibility around what you want to see and how the screen acts. As is its 'on rails' and Alexa seems to show whatever Amazon wants to show you and not based on any preference or interests you set. So that's a missed opportunity too.

It does work okay with our Ring doorbell which is one of the reasons I bought it. But that can also be subject to the slowness I noted above as well.

A bit lame for $200. For $400 I could get an iPad Mini and do 1000X more than this will do. Not very customizable visually at all. I can change the background and turn a few home screen options on or off. Trending Topics is totally irrelevant to me. I searched for ways to replace it with trending news stories from news sources that I like. So far there is no way to do this, even though this would be a very simple feature to add and would be much more useful than the trending topics. Finding good skills (i.e. apps) is difficult. For every 5 star skill available, there are fifty 1 star skills you have to look through. I do like the suggestions that cycle at the bottom of the screen. Try “Alexa ...”. This is actually useful along with the email they send you once a week with the same kind of tips. Overall, the UI is extremely basic and boring though. At this rate, you should wait for maybe the 5th generation if they are even still making these that long. The 2nd generation is unimpressive and I honestly feel like I wasted my money. Stick with the Echo Dot which is more reasonably priced.

reviews.reviewTitle: Room for Improvement, but surprisingly pleasant
reviews.reviewText:
Integration into the ecosystem. It is an all or nothing thing in my opinion. Our household is fully engulfed by Amazon. My 1 yr old's first word was "Alexa"!

I got the Show during Prime Day. As with all technology, in order to keep up with smooth functionality, devices need to be upgraded. The Show is definitely more responsive than my 1st gen Echo.

Pros:
Sound - for a multifunctional product, the sound the Show produces is quite impressive.
Responsiveness - Voice recognition is so sensitive that it sometimes picks up my voice from across the house

Cons:
