Interface - Some will argue it just is not meant for this type of UI. I feel it would definitely benefit from having more tablet like functionality. There is nothing worse than repeating yourself 5 times to no avail. As mentioned in some other reviews, trying to watch movies on the Show is complicated to say the least.
Integration - Alexa just isn't able to do everything the Show wants it to be able to do. I would love for everything to be hands-free, but only if it serves its purpose. Alexa responds quickly, but not always accurately.

Overall, it is great device. Especially if you can get it for under $150. I got the Show to provide easier access to my Ring Cams (another amazon product), and video chat with older relatives. For these purposes, it holds up its end of the bargain.

reviews.reviewTitle: "Things to Try" on home screen is beyond annoying, I won't be buying another one!
reviews.reviewText: For the most part this 2nd gen Echo Show does what it says. It still needs to do more things that make use of the screen (for weather and traffic) rather than just print the basic info. How about a google map with traffic? full details with pictures and radar for weather? The most annoying thing is the continually-scrolling "Things to Try" that cannot be turned off. While displaying nice pictures from a recent family wedding I see things across the bottom of the screen like "Try Alexa tell me a horse joke" or "Try Alexa tell me something weird" etc etc NON-STOP. My first intention was to "try" this Echo Show and see how much I liked it and then get another one for the main floor of the house (this one is in my office) and another one for the vacation house but because I can't tun of the "Things to try" on the screen I won't be buying another one.

reviews.reviewTitle: A must have. I’m a full out Alexa household now!
reviews.reviewText: I could go on all day! A must have.. I love the Ring Doorbell integration and the “Drop In” aka Intercom system.. I have a Show 5 in the Living room and the Show 2nd gen and dots throughout the house.. I can see what’s going on downstairs or even connect to my parents Show 5 I got for them for a video call.. I have the Philips Hue system to control all the lights and it links to all my TV’s, alarm system, doorbell, my music and video apps and stereo amps, so I can voice control my entire house now, thanks to the awesome Prime Days deals! Even if you just have it as a stand-alone device and have no Alexa compatible devices, it’s a must have!! I had 2 power strips that it discovered and I had no idea they were Alexa compatible! Very impressive system.. another reason it’s a must have is if you have a ring doorbell or any cameras with your alarm system, you just add an app, login and you can see/control everything. I have motion zones on my security cameras and I have it set to automatically pop up whichever cam was triggered. You can do that with Ring, too but I have it set to just say “Alexa, Show (video with audio from the camera but your audio is muted) or if you say answer front Door it pops up with your audio un-muted (so you can talk back and forth). Far too many features to mention here, but I absolutely love it now because I can control EVERYTHING in the house, even some things I had no idea were Alexa compatible that were found during discovery !

reviews.reviewTitle: Great device, a bit of a sound glitch.
reviews.reviewText: So far, I love my Echo Show 2nd generation. It was easy to set up. I highly recommend getting the kindle book for this device as it certainly helped answer any questions that I had. I did find a tech glitch that, from an internet search, may be common to the Echo Show. I had no sound, but when I unplugged the cord in back of the Show, waited a bit, and replaced it, the sound returned. If I do not unplug the device from the base before unplugging from the wall first when moving the show elsewhere, the sound disappears when I plug it back into the wall outlet. So.....always unplug it from the base first, if you have similar issues. Fantastic sound, by the way, and very stoutly built.

This 2nd generation Echo Show has a very large and bright, clear, crisp screen. It is hefty and build quality is solid. The 1st gen sitting next to it is dwarfed in comparison. It was easy to set up, just like the 1st gen. I'm hoping it doesn't develop the same annoying popping sounds that my 1st gen suffered from because it looks great on my desk and works seamlessly with my apps. I was a little disappointed in the sound quality, however. Due to the fact that they moved the speakers to the sides instead of having them fire forward, it becomes necessary to pay more attention to where the unit is placed (i.e., you have to pay attention to objects around it and how that impacts the sound deflection.) I realize this was a design choice in order to maximize the screen, so that's the trade off. This is my fifth Echo device. Each style (Dot, Tap, Show, etc.) has its place. Keep in mind, the 10 inch diagonal screen is contained in an 11 and one half inch frame. Take out a tape measure and be sure you have a place for something this big. As I live with my Echos, I find them to be more than just gimmicks or entertainment devices. Rather, they have become great tools to help with productivity in the office, garage, kitchen, and theater. Overall, I am very happy with this purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: One step forward, one back, more sideways.
reviews.reviewText:
Lacks even the level of integration of its predecessor. Example, forget trying to chose a night friendly clock face, it’s not supported yet. Forget the manual shutter to lock out the camera. They took it out (save < 1 Penney?). You can buy an add on but why should you have to? Trust their software? Only if you want hackers watching you.

The 5 is too small. This model is a bit too large for my use but I’m sure their are folks that will think that it’s too small.

Again, the base costs you extra as an option, no doubt costing more than if it were simply included (I’m sure Amazon loves that.)

Finally, ignoring all other faults of a simplistic language ability, there simply need to be independent settings for volume. Try turning out the bedroom lights without waking your wife. Thank you Alexa for screaming across the room. (Maybe she needs a nighttime voice.)

Finally, there needs to be an option in the software to set how long she listens without having to say “Alexa... Alexa... Alexa... every five seconds until she manages to understand what you really wanted.” Starting over because you named a movie and (the movie being unavailable) she started playing music instead. “This is what I found...”. “Don’t bother, it’s not what I asked you to play.”

Still waiting for real language recognition, not a menu of pre-programmed stupidity with a thin facade of comprehension.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is good when it does not hiccup, Amazon loves fire TV more than this
reviews.reviewText: Alexa is buggy and there is no GUI fallback. I ask Alexa to play a prime video and Alexa echoes with here is xxx season 3 episode 4, but it never plays. Alexa reboot yourself, cannot do that. No method to control prime video quality. On browser I can set it to eat .34Gb/h. On echo show it seems to eat 1.3Gb/h. There is no option to change quality unlike on fire TV or web browser. Fire TV has YouTube app support, this does YouTube on firefox and it is not good. Alexa, record pandora on cw. Sorry I could not find any enable video skills that can do that. I am watching it right now on the fire recast that I bought with the echo show, Alexa, how can you not find it. Alexa, record this show, Sorry I cannot find it. It is an android based device and yet it relies too much on Alexa to do everything when touch interface is still King. Now go to TV the fire TV app on my android phone, it cannot do scheduled recordings of a series, only what is on currently, that is not very convenient. Go to fire TV app, remote tab, it does not recognize echo show as device that can be controlled, unlike the fire TV. Why is Amazon's flagship device is secondary to toshibas' fire TV. Amazon, you don't even give your own flagship device all the features and support that you give to fire TV. Do you want echo show to fail? Do you want people to buy a Toshiba instead of this?

reviews.reviewTitle: Limited Functionality - Big Disappointment, BUT Getting Better
reviews.reviewText:
I've been interested in the Echo Show for awhile now, so during Prime Days I purchased a Show 5 and was quite impressed to use it as a state-of-the-art clock radio. With that positive impression, I purchased a second Show, the 10.1" second generation unit for my kitchen. What a disappointment, the Show 5 is an obviously more capable device. The first disappointment came when I found out you can NOT control the display time out. I want the Echo to display photos when on the home screen. Instead, the display shuts itself off (except showing the time) after a couple of minutes, and there is no setting to control or disable it going to sleep. It even goes to sleep when you are in the middle of watching the x-ray lyrics of a song being played. Secondly, it has no Alexa app skills to display documents or saved HTML. I want to display MY recipes that I have painstakingly accumulated over the years. I can save them as almost any format (.XLS, .DOC, .TXT, .PDF, or HTML, etc.), but the Echo Show is NOT capable of displaying ANY format. All it can do is display Alexa generated web images when you ask for a recipe. So much potential, but so limited, and so poorly implemented. My only hope is that they will improve the software over time. With Amazon's vast resources, improvements like these should be a 'no brainer'. Right now, its not even capable of being a decent electronic picture frame.

Update 8/5/2019
I can hardly believe it, but Amazon contacted me regarding this review, and we were able to talk through the display timeout issue. The rep agreed to submit my concerns to the development team regarding the display issue as well as my suggestions for future enhancements. Way to go Amazon for actually listening! I don't know if it was already in the works or not, but my Show 10.1" is now displaying Amazon Photos correctly, without the display going to sleep. The display still goes to sleep when showing background photos, but I have hope that will be corrected eventually. As for future enhancements, like being able to display MY recipes (instead of just random website recipes) I guess we'll have to just wait and see. I've decided to keep my Show, because it IS getting better, and Amazon actually listens. I've upped it from 2 to 4 stars - only 4 stars because there is so much potential still to be realized.

For some background we have had a ring doorbell for a little bit now and an echo dot. This is important because while it's not hard to pull out your phone to check on your ring feed, having the show is faster to pull up your ring feed and why not view it on the big pretty show screen? The show can also control your whole smart home if you have more smart devices that you want to use it with. Now on to why I mentioned having the echo dot. While I love our echo Dot and it is not a subpar device in anyway (has awesome voice recognition and Spotify sounds very good on it) the sound on the show is so so much better. It puts out every tone and beat in the songs and it can get very loud. Crystal clear quality. However if your wanting to get this for the sole reason of watching your Netflix or HBO I would recommend just getting an HD10 or even an HD8. While it's not impossible to watch these services on the show, there's a few extra steps you have to go through. If your watching solely prime video stuff it's flawless. Just get both if you can afford it! I have an HD8 and we haven't gotten an Amazon device that disappointed us :) All in all, the show can do so much, big pretty 10 inch screen, and the sound quality is amazinggg.

I had always wanted to have something like this in the kitchen. I had often used an iPad for looking at recipes. This just blows that concept away. Having the visual to along with things you already use everyday with Alexa is one of the best ideas Amazon has come up with. I love being able to see the lyrics for songs as they play. I love being able to watch my favorite movies and Prime originals from my Prime account while I'm cooking dinner. I love being able to see the weather forecast with icons and multi-day outlooks. I love being able to pull up recipes using "The Sous Chef" app. I love seeing everything that is on my shopping list as I create and add new items.

We have so many different Alexa enabled devices in our house and I can control everything from this amazing little hub. The screen allows me to dim lights I have in different zones in the house. I can check our baby's room with our Wyze camera. I can drop in on other rooms to communicate with the rest of the family when they are in a different section of the house instead of having to yell "dinner's ready!" at the top of my lungs. The sound quality is superb compared the generation 1 echo and echo dot devices. The picture quality is stunning for such a compact device. I watched one of "The Hobbit" movies the other day while cooking and I could not get over how crisp the picture and sound were.

Some things are not fully integrated yet, which is why I did not give it 5 stars. I have Kuna lights and I was hoping to be able to see my Kuna cameras at each door, but this hasn't happened yet. Also, there is no way to set a screen time out on it yet. You can turn off the screen by saying "Alexa, turn off screen" but otherwise it stays on for quite sometime before shutting down. Also, with the screen time out, if you are in a web browser, like Silk, watching something streaming online, it will go back to the home screen after a few minutes. This is frustrating if you are watching youtube videos or streaming content from Netflix or something like that.

Overall, I love this device. It has taken the great Alexa-enabled home we already have and enhanced it to juggernaut status. I think some of the things which are cons right now will eventually come through in the form of an update of the software. The price, design, and features are on point and worth the money. Thank you Amazon!

When I asked Alexa to call my dad, this Alexa automatically changes my command to “Drop-in”, and the call was automatically connected to my dad’s echo device and started showing the view of his echo device.
I have checked the log and it shows Alexa recognized my command correctly. It’s more like a server end issue.
I have contacted amazon on this matter but amazon has not sent me any conclusion yet.

We have so much fun with Alexa! She does useful things like display the day’s weather, and silly things like give you ideas of how to dress for that weather! (Linen jumper, espadrille, and a woven handbag for recent temps!) The home screen scrolls with pictures the kids ask her to take of them and suggestions for news stories, skills, or tasks she can complete. Every day my kids ask for the birthday lineup and what happened on this date in the past. We already had Echo Dots, but the suggestions on the Show have taught us so many new things we can ask her to do. She quizzes multiplication tables, tells the kids how to spell words, and was the center of family game night with Escape the Room (awesome!). I wake the kids up by asking her to play playlists on the Dots in their rooms and we listen to our music all over the house. If my big kids are home alone I can use my phone and to video chat on the Show and see that everything is all right. Love that I can visually see my shopping list and watch Prime shows right where I left off on my iPad. Once she kept NINE kids quiet at lunch by telling Disney stories. My own virtual personal assistant!

reviews.reviewTitle: This new Alexa Show 2.0 DOES NOT have all the features the old one does...
reviews.reviewText:
The size of the screen is a definite upgrade. The speakers sound great although 95% of the time use our surround sound speakers. This leads me to my top two complaints!
1. If you're selling an upgraded item, the new and improved, make sure it can do all the previous electric did + more. Especially when customers pre-order. The new Alexa show does not connect to your surround sound speakers properly. It sounds like headphones that are not plugged in all the way.
2. SUCKS to wait all year for the new product, pre-order it, pick it up and it cannot do one of the coolest features the old one did and your family uses A LOT!
So now the new Alexa show is sitting on my counter waiting for an update that hopefully will fix the issue. Definitely did not need to pre- order....

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible Reliability and Software Breaks it
reviews.reviewText: Received my 2nd Show as the first only lasted a year before dying. This one has made it about 1 month before the software update pushed bricked the speaker on it. Still responds and shows on screen but no matter resetting it to factory or every other option provided has addressed the issue. I've placed it on Facebook Marketplace to get some semblance of money back for it as it's utter garbage and after a couple hours on the phone with offshore representatives who pretend to be sympathetic to my issue and keep transferring me I'm simply done. I have several HomePods and they do what is needed and don't all start asking the same question when the "catch phrase" is used to invoke the AI assistant from the speaker. Save your money, buy a HomePod. Infinitely better speaker quality and voice recognition. This device is also creepy when you play your voice back on your account and what they are listening to.

Oh boy, what a mistake I made buying this.... I just don't get the disparity between the marketing to skill set of the equipment - this product seems to be a donosaur pre-release of something that could be good that's coming in the future that we don't get to have or enjoy because we bought the lesser functioning version FIRST. NO HOME SCREEN TO CONTROL THE MACHINE & it's capabilities are non-existent to VERY DIFFICULT to harness or control in ANY way. I would not have bought this had I known. I would like Amazon to give us updates that improve this machine, like allow WEB SURFING & an actual home screen to control this machine. Even if I watch Days of Our Lives online episodes, all it allows is to go forward or backwards but not to control a 'refresh' option when Alexa Show goes frozen for hours during a commercial or show... this product I thought was going to be sci-fi-fun absolutely perfect advanced technology - this system IS SO LIMITED IT'S a NIGHTMARE to try to operate. Voice commands are so minimal in scope and ability, I was shocked. What an overpriced product for just a wonderful speaker and a dinosauric operating screen even if it does have touch screen. Like I said, you can't refresh anything, you can't ask it to find a business, or a local transportation website which seem to show that it does not access the actual entire World Wide Web which is just loaded with useful information ti draw upon - no web surfing at all through it. In other words, it can't even do what the web can and go to a place to get you the information it couldn't give you. It had a hard time finding my purchased amazon music, it can't go to a website, it can't play online episodes well of things: IT FREEZES and no refresh button, no controls, no voice capabilities with these things. Alexa show also asks you to link your home computer though vicky something when you try to get it to reach a website, then cannot link your computer when you follow the instructions for that - there's something wrong here - Amazon, where is the complete list of what this product even does other than weather or something very miniscule? I am shocked, I thought this would be sci-fi type fun it would be so advanced & am just shocked at how very little this Alexa Show can do. Positives are it does play really good radio stations and you can ask it to tell you how to say some common foreign language sentnces or words.

While I liked the original Echo Show, it often felt like a version 1 of a product. I didn't care very much for the design of the product, the looks, and the screen size/quality. When Amazon offered deep discounts on the new Echo Show if you traded-in your 1st gen Show, I decided to take the plunge. We mostly use our Echo's for listening to Amazon Music, and for the price the Echo's, including the Show, performed well. Gen 1 of the Show had good but not great sound. The screen was good but not great. Gen 2 addresses both of these issues and as a result, the product feels and looks like what the Show should have been all along.

This biggest and best part of the gen 2 Show is the screen. The screen is basically the whole front of the device and it looks really good. Out of the box I had to adjust the brightness as the default setting was too low. Everything on the gen 2 screen looks good. From song lyrics to 5 day weather forecast, the screen is bright, clear, and with good resolution. I recently purchased the Amazon Fire Recast device which allows you to stream "over air" TV to your Fire devices and to your Echo Show. On the gen 1 Show, watching tv was difficult because of the screen size and quality. With gen 2 Show, watching TV is much better. The screen size and clarity fo the screen make watching local news/tv a pleasure. The screen is nice enough that streaming Prime Videos is nice as well.

The sound on gen 2 is also improved. The sound is louder and fuller. Out of the box the bass is too much and drowned out the rest of the music. The Show has an equalizer setting that allows you to adjust the bass and treble. The gen 1 Show did not come close to the sound regular Echo's can provide so I generally listened to music over the Echo's rather than the Echo Show, unless specifically in the kitchen where my Show is located. Now with gen 2, the sound is good enough that it is not a compromise.

The big question is, is the gen 2 worth the upgrade from gen 1? Absolutely, especially if you can get it at the discounted prices. At full price it is still a good upgrade but may not be worth it depending on your particular use. For me, listening to music and watching TV improvements would make the full price a generally good value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing sound - BUT - Lacks basic touchscreen support and software functionality.
reviews.reviewText:
Got 2 on Black Friday. Heres my review and criticisms of this device. Im confused and conflicted about this device. I feel like Amazon knows they need to improve on the software. Pros : Sounds amazing - 11/10. Like seriously, the bass on this thing is wow. It's really clear.

Now onto the cons.. On my phone, I can touch anywhere, and get a response. There needs to be a back button, there needs to be swipe functionality, like from the bottom up on an iPhone. Im touching parts of the UI on the Show expecting it to do something, and Im frustrated that I can/cant click on certain things that are or arent obvious. There needs to be a Device list similiar to how I control my devices via my Android on my phone.

I can say Alexa (show) turn on Philips Hue. I get the Device, it pops up. I even get a brightness bar. But I cant view any of these devices whatsoever in the 30 Internet-of-thing type devices I have connected to the Alexa ecosystem. What. Why? I dont have friends. I dont use this for making calls or video calls. Thats what phones are for. This product should really be relagated or somehow updated via software to include alot of the features lacking.

The homescreen is extremely limited. There needs to be way more access to font sizes, font types, what shows up on the home screen. I mean come on, Google killed it. There needs to be options for screen "timeout". Just take a page from Android 9.0 or whatever.

If Amazon takes into account these comments seriously - and I think they do, especially with the always learning doomsday robot named Alexa, she'll probably write code just based on reading this comment.

Edit (1 hour later) - Seems Amazon does take these comments seriously. I got a phone call - asking for feedback. Not even an hour after posting this review. I further explained my situation. Interesting. Gave them more feedback on the ecosystem. I think it really comes down to Software. The hardware is great. Few other things mentioned. Im still unsure whether I will be keeping the device. It is cool to note that they do (for obvious reasons, they read the comments) just wasn't expecting a call or anyone to care or read. As busy as they are, and to receive a followup call. Hope my voice recorded feedback helps, Mr. Bezos.

I have both generation 1 and 2 of Alexa show. I bought the generation2 with hopes of it being better at hearing my voice from across the room. I have not found that to be the case. I have had the new show for about 3 months now and I love the new features with the new one. The screen is much better, as is the sound system. I bought the swivel stand and the screen protector and I am glad I did. Not that anything has happened to it, I have it sitting in my kitchen area and that is always a good idea to have as a safe guard for your Alexa device. Some of the key differences between the devices are the ability with version 2 to have a freetime, where you can restrict activity. Hunches is where you have a connected device that you think or have a "hunch" may have been left on too long, you can have Alexa check on it. One real feature I love is the Guard feature. Guard feature detects if your smoke or CO detectors goes off, if there is glass breakage, and can set away lighting. The Guard feature only notifies you if any of these occur it doesn't call authorities, that is left up to your security system. However, I like having the notifications coming to my phone so I can remember to us the drop in feature on Alexa to see what is going on. There are other version2 features but these are the 2 biggest new features that really make buying the new one worth the argument. The Amazon support is great and seem to be really up to speed with any technical issues or questions you have. Overall I love the new version vs the old one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Huge improvement over the Echo Show first generation
reviews.reviewText:
We have a great many Alexa devices, dating back to the original Echo 'tower' device, but also including the Echo Show original model. We were never terribly impressed with those; it was nice having a touchscreen, but it was too small and while the sound was okay, it was nothing special either. Well, the 2nd generation Echo Show has a screen the size of a tablet and much, much better sound. I had been thinking about buying the Echo subwoofer, but I don't think it's really needed with this Echo Show; the only way to improve it much more would be to pipe the audio to the stereo receiver.

We also got the adjustable stand for it, which is nice, but honestly it should be a standard included component rather than an add-on accessory.

I deducted a star for the same complaints I had for the first generation Echo Show: Please, Amazon, give us the ability to TURN OFF the "Try "Alexa, (some random command" suggestions. I hate them. Customers have been asking for this option since the day the Show was first released two years ago. And second, give us the means to display the clock (customizable would be best) and/or weather larger on the screen, like with the new Echo Show 5.

I have two of these. They are great for watching the Ring doorbell camera. The sound quality is good. The voice recognition is not as good as my echo or echo dots. Even my Ecobee thermostat pics up the wake word better. It's not bad, It just isn't great like the other devices. It does not interface with the SmartThings camera, which is a major disappointment. It would also be great if it could interface with standard IP cameras, but I doubt that is going to happen. My wife uses one in the kitchen. I have one by the couch in the living room. It is supposed to work with Hulu, but every time I tried to connect it, I had problems. I no longer have Hulu. So, it doesn't matter now. If it had more streaming services like a Roku or a FireTV, I'd get one for the office.

I like being able to send announcements using the onscreen keyboard. The announcement recordings never sound that good. Using Alexa's voice to make announcements is much better.

Lyrics for songs is nice. The screen quality is good. The size is right.

Basically, I think this device has potential, but it is not worth the full price. I got both of mine when they were heavily discounted.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic device with quality control flaws
reviews.reviewText:
Compared to the show v1, this is a massive upgrade. The sound system, and the display make this device so much more comforting to both look at and use. Voice recognition is fantastic, sometimes maybe a little too good. However, this device has many more flaws than expecting.
The first show v2 I had came with a type of "ghost tap", where the screen taps without you actually tapping there. Not normally a noticeable problem, but when typing anything or scrolling through a page with hyperlinks, automatically typing in an extra letter or jumping away from the page is extremely annoying. Contacted amazon, and they replaced it. Great customer service. The replacement device started working fine and obviously came in pristine condition. This time, the bluetooth was the one that began malfunctioning. The bluetooth would break connection, which by itself is not a huge problem. However, the echo claimed that my iPhone was still connected when it clearly wasn't. Turning off bluetooth on the phone did nothing. The echo still remained "connected" to the phone - when it wasn't. Not a horrible problem, so I tried to manually remove the phone and commence repairing. However, the show refused to disconnect from the phone. It would say "disconnecting" yet would never actually disconnect. It was only after a factory reset that the phone was truly disconnected, and the problem was seemingly gone. Paired just fine, music played just fine, yet a few minutes in, the problem happened again, and now, Amazon has gone to try and solve the problem.

Another complaint I have is the home screen. Mainly, about why the time remains so small. It's got a massive screen, with a lot of just background space, so why not let us, the consumers, customize it more? I'd love to enlarge that time display, and be able to utilize the home screen the way I want it to.

All in all, with the issues solved, this is a phenomenal device that I'd love to have back in my life.

The Alexa Show is a big pile of poo. I have to shut it off and restart it constantly (per their tech support advise) as well as disconnect it from our internet and then reconnect it every time I use it. It doesn’t switch between windows while it is idle. It just shows what you should say for the things you like and want to see like the news. I have had it for two months and it has red lined me three times. It is really frustrating. It may be going back. My lap top sitting on the counter works better. How ever if you want it just for music it works nicely and the sound is great. But I would have gotten a blue tooth speaker if I needed just music.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hate the forced "Try" recommendations at the bottom
reviews.reviewText:
Have tried all suggestions on how to turn these off and none work. Many are really indirect advertisements "Try: Alexa what are the features of XYZ product. " None are wanted.
Otherwise, nice screen and good sound. But can't believe people put up with this. Mine is going back to Amazon.

I waited about a month to see how I liked it and I can tell you that I neither love it or hate it. The echo show is just OK. I bought this to replace our original echo and I really don't think it sounds as good. I have played a lot with the equalizer to try and make it sound better but still has a funny bass sound and just doesn't sound like I would like it. It doesn't sound bad just not as clear as I had hoped.
I was also hoping that it would also do better at picking up voice commands but does about the same as the old unit. The addition of the screen is nice sometimes but not as much as I was thinking. It can also be very distracting for little kids that tend to be drawn to screens. I am always telling the unit to turn off the screen.
Probably the most annoying thing is the volume control. It would be nice if it could normalize the volume. Different apps YouTube, Amazon music, etc. all play at different volumes. You also can not control the volume of her voice separately from the main volume. So if you have to turn up the volume high to hear a video on YouTube or another app the voice volume is crazy loud. It would be nice to have a system (voice) volume control separate from the main volume. Maybe this will be fixed with an system update or something in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: One drawback keeps this from being a 5 star device.
reviews.reviewText:
Not going to beat around the bush here, the next version of this device must be able to tilt the camera out of the box. I mean really, this is my only issue. Where it sits, or really anywhere in my house it is always aimed up at the ceiling which means there is typically a light in the background and as anyone that has ever taken a photograph knows when you have a light in the background it will darken the overall image to adjust for exposure. If you look at the second picture I posted you can see how it has a very high angle, capturing more of the ceiling than the rest of the room. This was done so you can stay in frame while talking, however with those lights in the background I or anything I am trying to show someone on the camera come through darker making it difficult to see details unless I move to block the lights with my body or whatever I am holding up. The ability to either tilt the camera or adjust exposure manually would help this issue. Second, we are about to have out first child and my in-laws live about an hour away. They wanted a way to be closer to the family without always having to drive back and forth. So when I purchased this device I also purchased one for them. My initial idea was to put one in the nursery so they could "drop-in" on the baby, issue is all they will be able to drop-in on is the ceiling and maybe a top rail of the crib. So unless I am in there holding the echo and showing them the baby or holding the baby in front of the echo it just won't work the way I wanted it to. Which is why it is now in the kitchen.

Hopefully Amazon will design this feature in to the next version of the echo show. Until then I think I am going to grab either the tilt stand for the echo show 2nd gen (while it will help, it sucks having to purchase something that could have been built in and I don't know if it will tilt down far enough to accomplish what I want) or I can purchase an Echo Spot and a tilt able wall mount that I can mount above the crib.

Everything else about the Show 2nd gen is amazing. Speakers are great, has very clear audio even at high volumes. Image quality is good. The presence of the device is unobtrusive. Amazing build quality. I love the device. Just wasn't expecting such a high angle on the camera, it may be obvious to some but it took me a bit by surprise once I started to use it.

I really find I use the Echo devices more than I ever thought I would I have found that lately they have issues with understanding requests. It's not just myself or on one device so I wonder what happened to make it worse rather than better. It's not horrible but definitely annoying! In general the Echo devices are wonderful and the echo Show2 is definitely the best of all of them. I do have a suggestion...I do feel they should make a water resistant and easily cleanable version for those who would like to have an Echo Show in the bathroom or kitchen or even an out door version for people who would like one for thier yard. This is a wonderful item but it will not be good for a kitchen where it could have something splashing on it. Many people don't realize that YOU CAN TURN OFF THE CAMERA AND MIC by just taping the button on top. I also recommend that those who only want to turn off the camera occasionally but keep on the mic ....if you don't want to have to go into settings...to turn the camera off...buy these stick on camera covers with a slide button. It doesn't damage the screen and works great! They are also cheap. I think I paid about $4 for 8 of them.

reviews.reviewTitle: A fun way to experience what Alexa can offer.
reviews.reviewText:
Good looking screen, well performing device that gets loud. Make no mistake, this is not a high resolution TV for streaming your favorite Prime video channels, nor is it the perfect sounding speaker to stream Amazon music, but it does both of those things quite well.

There are not many skills that take advantage of the display on this echo device, but I like the simple clock that it is for most of my day.

The touch screen performs well and the microphone seems to work better than on my echo dots.

In terms of sound, it gets loud and it sounds pretty good, but it does a weird thing with bass. It's almost like there is a dedicated driver for bass, and that it's coupled with a vibration motor, because if you can feel it, it's deeper, right? I don't know what it is, but it's overemphasized to my ears, giving the impression that it's trying too hard to be a great speaker, instead of settling for just being a really good speaker.

The mute button is convenient, but I'd have liked to see a shutter for the camera as well. Ultimately, I'd have liked to use this echo device in the bedroom, but not with that camera on it. It shall remain in the 'public' parts of my home.

In the end, I can recommend the echo show to anyone looking for a smart speaker with a display, but is invested in the Amazon ecosystem. Amazon really needs to solve this feud with Google, it is a mistake to not have YouTube on this device.

Every time I unplug power brick from the wall and plug it back, it boots without sound; it works, but does not produce any sound at all. The only fix is to unplug the power plug from the back first. So in case you need to move your device, you have to unplug the back power connector, not only power brick. That is really annoying because I move my Echo Show every time to use it as TV on patio, and there is no power bank for 2nd generation on the market. That is a known issue, and there is a discussion about that on Amazon forums:
https://www.amazonforum.com/forums/devices/echo-alexa/507844-echo-show-2nd-gen-no-sound
Also there is no option to customize screen saver clock anymore. It was there in 1st generation, and it is there on Echo Show 5, but it was removed from the most expensive version!
If they not fix these troubles during 1 month, I will have to return the product back.

Wow! Deciding between Echo Show and Google Home is tough because most reviewers don’t own either. I finally decided on Echo Show because it controls more things, allows video chats, has a bigger screen, and gives me extras at no cost because of my Prime Membership (like Amazon Music).

Be aware that you need to decide which control convention to go with (Z-wave or Zigbee). I chose Zigbee because the switches and plugs that use Zigbee seemed to be a little cheaper than Z-wave devices. That means Echo’s higher cost can be offset by cheaper accessories. As you add more items, the difference adds up.

WiFi controlled devices will work with either Echo or Google but could begin to slow down your Internet due to traffic jams in your router. Z-wave and Zigbee apparently don’t go through the router.

Also be aware of the feud between Amazon and Google is kind of like between Sony’s Beta Max VCR and the VHS format. One will win and half of us will be left with outdated technology.

Smart ahome setup is beyond the capabilities of most home owners and you may need the help of a Tech Guru at additional cost. But if you just want to plug it in and surf while you cook, it’s not too hard to do.

Being able to check who’s at the front door, see when packages arrive, remotely control lights, are all easier for those with limited mobility, but they still need enough tech smarts to be able to make it work. Probably not a good option for a Grandparrent who doesn’t know how to use their smart phone.

Wish the screen wouldn’t timeout so fast or Atleast have an option that you could change that setting. Would like to be able to monitor my cameras without always asking Alexa.
Overall this thing has everything. The sound quality is amazing. Picture quality is perfect. I’m still messing with it and trying to figure out how I can use this in everyday life as I’m slowly transitioning my house to be a full smart house. But for now with cooking and listening to music this thing is amazing. Add a screen time out setting and I’d give it 5 stars.

I love my Echo Show. I first saw one of these while visiting a friend and had to go out and buy one the next day.
First of all, I am totally ignorant when it comes to this kind of technology but from the minute I took it out of the box and plugged it in the on screen step by step instructions had it operational in no time.
Now when I want to know sports scores, listen to a certain song I suddenly thought about from years ago, find out what movies are playing near me, etc I just ask Alexa. While playing music the sound is excellent.
Yesterday I thought I had a problem with it since Alexa was not responding so I logged onto the Amazon Echo web site and in less than a minute I discovered what the problem was. The customer rep, Miranda, whom I could actually understand because she had no accent, was so helpful and knew immediately what I needed to do. I was actually embarrassed how simple the solution was.

I have had the 1st Gen Echo Show in my kitchen since November 2017. Alexa has changed out whole household. She has brought music, fun and laughter to our kitchen, making it our favorite space to hang out together. Last month, I decided to buy the 2nd Gen because I loved the bigger screen. I deeply regret my purchase. The 2nd is glitchy. It freezes, stops in the middle of songs, and has horrible voice recognition. Half the time, Alexa doesn't hear her own name, even if the music isn't too loud. The speaker, to me, sounds more fuzzy and artificial. The glitching is out of control, she talks when we are in the living room far away, she doesn't respond to her own voice, she can't hear you with the music playing. The on screen lyrics don't show, I have to tell her to put them back on constantly, and my screen is always black, never showing the clock or screensaver until I wake her up. Very disappointed with this glitchy unit. I have also tried to update, and everytime I select update in the settings, it freezes. My 1st Gen is about to go back in it's comfy spot and this 2nd Gen can go back in the box. It's not worth the trouble.

I received my Alexa Echo Show 2nd Gen and loved it from the start. The sound quality was great, the AI intuitive, and voice recognition did amazing at even understanding me with food in my mouth. Within 20 days, the screen flickered and lines went across it. The next day the screen didn't even respond. The device still worked as an Echo but no longer showed you anything. I called support to get help and they had me ship it back. It was never mentioned it was being sent to a 3rd party to be evaluated to be repaired or replaced.
To me, this should have been an immediate replacement and apology. It was within the first 30 days. Its technology, you can't control every little semiconductor or the fluctuation in power going to it. So, I understand some will fail. Most happen within the first 30 days. As a consumer, I don't believe I should have to be waiting for any device to be repaired within the same month I bought it.
Support on the other hand, was trying over and over to justify why I should wait. So that way I can be happy to get my original device I purchased back in 1 to 2 weeks. I guess what I should have done, was sent it back as broken. Then, bought a new one. It would have cost me nothing and I would have my new one in the mail the next day.
I was a computer tech for 10 years, I sold computers and their parts, as well as, fixed them. In those years of sales experience I would have never thought about telling my customer that just purchased an item, they would have to wait until someone else (other than me or my shop) evaluated the item to determine the issue and then decide to fix or replace that item.
So, I guess in the end, it was poor support and quality that is forcing me to give this device a 2 star rating.

reviews.reviewTitle: The potential for greatness is there.
reviews.reviewText:
The Echo Show is a good addition to my echo ecosystem. I have the original Echo, Echo Dot, Echo 2, and the Fire TV Cube. I wish I can give this more stars.
Pros: the screen is clear the integration with my ring doorbell and some of my other cameras are great and the Hub features very convenient.
Cons: the sound quality if the screen is facing you the sound is not that great if you're facing the speakers the sound is amazing. The other issue I've had is my microphone there's 8 microphones and it still has a problem hearing is especially if the TV is on but my Fire TV queue which is right next to the TV here's me very well.
I think with a few software updates they can make this unit great and I can give him more stars. Also still waiting for some of the features that it will promise but it's still not activated.

I bought a 2nd Gen Echo Show, and it immediately presented issues (from the camera) I could see it in my screen of my image and my callers could see it on their screen. I spent 1 hour or more with Tech support, no fix, and received 3 emails once a week they were still looking into it. My software was and is up to date. So I returned the first one. Bought another (on sale this time) and magically the same issues.....I own 9 echo devices, I am an early adopter, but this is truly impacting my trust in the Amazon brand, it took me 30 mins to get a replacement sent out...This should not be so hard to fix, both the hardware issue and the customer service!

I love my amazon products and am slowly connecting everything in my house. I have multiple Alexa devices. The show is the most expensive and the most worthless. It is so frustrating that I want to return but passed return date. It can’t find anything and when you finally get where you want to go, like a recipe, as soon as you turn to get an egg it goes to home screen. My daughter asked me why I was yelling at Alexa. Don’t waste your money on this. It is completely useless.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful option for video calls with aging parents
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this, so I could "call" my parents, who live in Memory Care. I love that I can "drop in" automatically, without them having to get to the phone. It works wonderfully. All I say is "Alexa, drop in on parents" and walla! It auto-answers on their end, and the video of their room goes opaque for about 10 seconds (for privacy purposes), and the Echo Show "announces" that I am calling them. I can even mute the call (which also turns off my video), and still see/hear them (they can't see me when I'm muted, but they can see a small video image of their room in the top corner of the Show's screen, so they know they're still on video). It sits on my desk, so when I'm in between calls/projects, I "drop in" on my parents several times a day. Great for monitoring my parents (and their caregivers, who are pretty darn good).

You can also make 2-way video calls from the Alexa app on your phone. Not as nice of an experience, but it's nice when you're away from your Echo.

The only thing I don't like/understand, is why it's mandatory to associate their contact with a phone number (video calls go over the internet, so they don't need a phone number). I hope they fix this in the future.

To be honest, I haven't used the Echo Show for much else, except to play my favorite radio station, K-LOVE (positive, encouraging).

We got my in-laws a Google Home for all of 20min until we realized they were Prime users and my MIL was a big Amazon Music user. My brother had just gotten me an Echo Show so we returned the Google and got them a show instead.

The Good:
I will say this integrated much quicker than the Google Home since I'm a Prime User. Setup was extremely simple where as with Google I don't use it much more than for an old email account.

I really enjoy the screen. Calling up a News Flash, weather, shopping list and being able to see it was really nice. Screen is only 720p but honestly at this size you cannot tell.

Sound quality is pretty good. We've got an echo dot and you can absolutely tell the difference. We have an open floor plan downstairs and the sound travels well from the kitchen to the living room.

It works with my Nest products (google owned) with one or two minor issues I'll add in the Cons. But it can control my thermostats and pulls video from my doorbell camera.

Has a built in Smart HUB which is great. Makes pairing other smart devices extremely easy. Usually the echo show can detect automatically which is a plus and if it's another amazon product it's extremely easy.

Works extremely well with Amazon Music and Spotify.

It does have a working web browser and can connect to Youtube. It can also call up recipes easily.

Shopping list is fantastic and the phone app pairs nicely to it.

Bad or Could be Better:
It can connect and show video to my Nest Hello camera but no sound. Nest is Google owned so they don't always play nicely together. Not a huge deal though.

My other Nest complaint was the Nest Skills you must download on the show. I would select the Doorbell and it would take me to the security camera skill. I eventually learned through some message boards to just download the security camera skill and it should recognize it which it eventually did. Just took some time.

One noticeable difference is Google's AI is better. It understood me far more frequently and did not struggle with questions nearly as much. Alexa isn't bad, it just isn't as good.

Some setting features are in the Show and some are in the app you have to download. I found it a little clunky especially on the show side.

The whole skills thing so far seems lacking. It looked like a bunch of junk so far or that's at least the recommendations I keep getting. I'm more interested in productive integration...not jeopardy.

Video calling works. But the recipient has to have a Show or the app downloaded. Just like facetime on Apple, you can't use it on an Android. Most of us seem to have an iPhone so no big deal there, but this is a much smaller market at this point. I've heard skype is coming soon so that should help. I haven't done a Show to Show call yet so I cannot comment.

Not a big fan of how shopping on prime has been setup. It feels super limited so I'll stick to a computer for purchases.

Overall:
Really like this product. If you're a Prime user it's fantastic for music, video, shipping notifications and delivery. If not it might not be as great but it's still a smart speaker so it doesn't lose too many points. I think they could iron out a few issues regarding software design and making it more intuitive, and they could deff spend a few dollars getting Alexa to Goggle AI levels. I will say I'm still learning to full capabilities of this device so my opinions could greatly improve in the future as I learn more features and add my smart products to my home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't play well with Pandora. I have had to do numerous factory resets!
reviews.reviewText:
I have had to reset this device almost every time I play my Pandora stations. I will say "Alexa stop", no luck, "Alexa off", again no luck. Occasionally it will appear to stop playing Pandora music but when I come back later and ask to play again I am told Pandora is already playing, but there is no music playing.

Added the Echo Sub and that was another layer of fun. It works when it wants to. Most of the time I end up having to delete the pairing and go through the painful steps of creating a new sub pair, then repeat it sometimes the same day, others a day or two later.

Amazon released these devices way before they were ready for prime time! I have to admit the sound is great when they are working together but the time I spent making them work is really worth the sound quality improvements.

Hopefully Amazon is working on some software updates that make this product pair a much more enjoyable experience.

Until there is some improvements in both products software I can't recommend either.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent quality, UI needs to utilize the touchscreen more.
reviews.reviewText: It can’t multitask. And no Netflix. Say you’re listening to music or watching a YouTube video in the web browser or watching Hulu if you ask Alexa to set a timer. It cancels out whatever you were doing just to display the timer. Then you have to go back and restart whatever you were doing before. Also if you’re watching Hulu and you are finished you can’t say “Alexa Stop” or “Alexa stop playing” it doesn’t do anything. You have to say “Alexa go home” which doesn’t feel very intuitive. And it would be nice to have some Audio EQ options don’t get me wrong the sound quality is pretty amazing for the size but I would like to turn down the sub just a little because it vibrates all the knives and plates that are sitting on my counter and creates a negative listening experience. Would also be nice to have quick access to apps and other functions on screen instead of requiring you to use voice commands 100% of the time. Physically this thing is clean and solid good quality, software wise functionally it works well, the UI needs some more improvement. I’m glad I got it and also glad I waited for the 2nd gen to release before buying.

Doesn’t work 90% of the time. You have to consistently unplug it almost every other command. Won’t play music when you ask unless you unplug it and you may have to unplug it right after you just unplugged it just to hope to get it working. Contacted support and they make it extremely hard to get a replacement almost as if you will never get a replacement. You can only return through ups and you can only go to specified locations. No easy way to return. The easiest return is to have ups pick it up but they give you a 10 hour window when they might be there. So make sure you have no life or plans or no emergencies to go to while you wait.

reviews.reviewTitle: Video has me pulling my hair out, but thats its big feature! Updated review.
reviews.reviewText:
Ok, its a good display, the sound is very good, the voice recognition is 50/50. But to get any video to happen is a nightmare! Try to play a video from Prime by name-forget it! Try and try again, no luck. Try to go to home screen for Prime videos? No idea how to get there. Nothing seems to work.

How about playing live streams on Hulu? Say “Play Hulu”, wait a while and you have the Hulu app. Touch the display to pick channels, wait. Pull down through channels to find CNN and touch it, wait. Now touch live and recents, wait. Now touch the live show and wait again, this time a long time. Finally a live stream!

But oh no, its a commercial and I want to change to MSNBC or FOX. Forget it! Its back through the entire sequence again just to change channels.

Yes you can say, "play CNN on Hulu" and then to change channels say “play Fox News on Hulu”, but it will consistently fail to stream the second choice. Unreliable and frustrating.

Compared to my phone, laptop or a Roku its like going back to the 80’s. Too late for me to return this beast, but the primary thing I bought it for just isn't worth it. I am going back to using a tablet and my original Echo.

6/28
Update: Excellent customer support means I will raise the review to three stars. They reached out right away. However, they couldn't really make it work any better/faster.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great upgrade and worth the price
reviews.reviewText:
Screen has light bleed issues and backlight consistently issues

EDIT
the screen is literal trash, i watch movies on it from prime video and the backlight is so bad. From the Gen1 they made some progress with the screen-glass distance but in putting a larger screen they made it of poor quality. This screen would be fine for a $50 tablet but not for this price. i know Amazon can do better We have seen it on the more expensive tablets (still cost less than echo show gen 2). Also in putting a larger screen amazon forgot to upgrade the RAM, GPU and CPU as a result this model is slower then last year's. Amazon took 2 steps forward and 3 steps back

Edit
My unit was defective and all issues involving the screen have been fixed! That being said this is an excellent way to control smart home. Passive bass radiator makes all the difference!
I wouldn't go as far as to say that amazon hit a home run with this one but they are light years ahead of the market/competition with this one.

It only took 2 generations to perfect the Show, not bad right? I have the original echo, a few dots, the echo show 1st gen and now the second gen. In my case these products are my favorite toys. I’m a prime member and have tons of subscriptions through Amazon, a massive movie collection etc.... I love the first gen show, but there were two things that prevented it from being all I wanted, or rather one. I don’t watch movies on a phone, but I will on a tablet. The 2nd gen has a bigger flatscreen that will work great with streaming, and i don’t have to hold it (yes I could buy a tablet stand, but with the echo it’s nit necessary.).

The thing that impressed me most about the original echo, and the dot is that Alexa really could as advertised hear you from a good distance away and speaking casually, and she would respond. The first show was a big step back in that one aspect. You almost had to be facing it and and you didn’t have to shout, but it was a regression.

This second generation has a bigger screen, nicer sound, and it will hear you and act from much further away compared to the first gen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Definitely better speakers, I just have issues with the Alexa voice service
reviews.reviewText:
The device is basically an Android tablet with speakers and no accelerometer, so most critique goes towards the Alexa service, I believe they're Lambda functions for a voice server. I can't really filter what news shows up, so I see sports even though sports is a meaningless pastime of a primitive society. You can't tell it to never play a genre of music either, so if it mishears a Metal band name, it will play a rap band... not something a person would do.

If you're trying to play a song on Unlimited, but only have the regular subscription, sometimes it "mishears" it, sometimes it goes to an app that has that song (radio app), and sometimes it will do the ad to upgrade, and that ad is relatively long, every time, and no way to tell it automatically "no" until you hear the whole spiel. It's very annoying.

The translation will censor words, even harmless insults become "beep" noises.

The Audible controls are nice, and the fact you can have music or books stop in any amount of time, or skip X seconds/minutes is awesome. Unfortunately Audible likes to open to your last book by default, so you have to remember the specific command to display all books.

Ready apps include sleep noises, but the playlist for Sleep using music, and electronic music, is filled with a bunch of songs with blaring noises and only half of them work, while the other half just wake you up. Reminiscent of those grocery-store cheap CD's with "Sleep music" that has crashing cymbals for who-knows-why

It has a great array of working items, combined with so many that don't you find yourself not trusting it.
Once the trust is broken you stop using it. You stop asking questions to Alexa, effectively disabling the point of owning the device.

I'm happy with the purchase because I was told the speaker system on this version was the best. It absolutely is. It is room filling, with tons of bass. It's quite amazing, really.

There's a few things like timers, and lists that work better with a visual display, but it feels like they haven't worked on Alexa's vocabulary or fields of understanding at all. She says she doesn't know to a LOT of things.

Hulu, does not work for me. I'm seeing a good mix of people who say it does and some saying it doesn't, but it will not connect to my login. It is also unstable at the login screen.
There's a 'screen captcha' anti-bot segment to the login.
I went through this thing 6 times.. At first it would barely load. It did seem to speed up, and I changed my login just to make sure I had a very simple one for the interface.
If you get through the captcha with the correct login and password, it tells you that 'Hulu is not available at this time. Try again later.'

I had a first attempt get stuck on this screen and not allow me to go back into the login section. I reset to factory defaults to get it back.

This device.. It feels like an early 2000's piece of tech. It doesn't have that apple slick feel to it where everything just works, and obviously they released it slightly unpolished.

I also can't get my nest thermostat to link.
There's a huge lack of slickness to the pairing of external devices and services that I find very disappointing. Considering how simplified and scaled down a device this is, what exactly is it if it can't operate external devices particularly well and doesn't do as much as a tablet?

We also own the 4K firetv cube, and the same problem happens. It wants you to be able to use it hands free, and encourages you to try, but because many of the things it wants you to do don't yet work well, (such as navigation and being stuck in netflix with no way to tell it to navigate towards the title called "bah blah", and having her tell you she doesn't know what the hell you mean), you realize immediately that it doesn't work well enough to let you do anything that the very first original echo could do, so, err.. Why does it exist?

For the cube, you immediately go back to the remote, and for the show, you realize that you just got an original echo with a screen, and you won't be using it for anything else.

For me, it's a decent bluetooth speaker that gives good weather reports.

I like the speaker.. I like all the original things I liked about the original echo, but the visualization and video apps are currently being wasted.
They would have been better off merging a full tablet with alexa, then at least you could navigate to and use hulu, and a web browser, etc etc while they catch up with her abilities.

I'll update my review if they update and fix some problems. I really see a future in this series, but they need to slow it down and get it working better before crossing a platform into visual with a format that can't take advantage of it yet.
It causes disappointment and brand wariness.

*update*
I attempted to login to hulu once again, and it simply worked right away.
No idea what the issue was, but there was no delay. Just straight in.
Also, I finally got my nest thermostat to pair. If I was of a suspicious mind, I would think it had something to do with my bad review that Amazon then contacted me over :D
Deals a deal though. I'll raise the stars to 3 and hope they will work on her abilities that she has right now, not continuously add trinkets to a half working idea.

Barely functional, no Netflix, no Hulu, no YouTube, Amazon Video is stripped down and barely works. It was a real expensive disappointment. A pricey heavy clock.

Update: a rep from amazon called. They told me there is Hulu and YouTube how we I wouldn’t know as the attached video is what happens when I go to give it some pretty simple commands. My fire tv cube, and echo dots are great. This is not.

I own two of the first generation Echo Shows. I love them both. Upgrading to the 2nd generation was a no brainer with the larger screen and speaker. However, the Show still has a ways to go before Amazon gets it right.

1. Yes, speaker is larger and more powerful but you lose the intended effect when the speaker points away from you. The actual sound experience for someone standing in front of the Show is a disappointment and actually felt more like a downgrade. Amazon needs to address the directional flow of sound better. The round Echo's are great in terms of projecting sound throughout the room because of it's shape and position of speakers. . . obviously. The Show is too directional and moving sound away from you is not an upgrade in my humble opinion.

2. Tried the video call yesterday and I was shocked. Streaming can be fairly choppy and reminiscent of some of the first web cams that came out onto the market. Low resolution. . . Don't expect to see anywhere close to the same quality streaming as you will get watching something from the Amazon library. Amazon dropped the ball on this one.

I was hoping to pick up additional units as gifts, but at this point, I'll wait until next year to see how Amazon improves upon this year's mode. While I love the larger screen, I would not recommend an upgrade unless you really want the larger screen and don't mind turning the Show around to benefit from the larger speakers.

And finally. . . Amazon decided to take a picture of my package at the front door with a link that asks me how I feel about posting a picture online. Seriously? While the picture is only visible in my account, my first thought was that they're trying to move away from any culpability if thieves steal from your house. I have an enclosed patio, out of site from the street. What's to keep a dishonest delivery person from picking up the package after it's been documented online as delivered? Not everyone may feel this way, but it felt like a violation of privacy and an effort which came across a little too aggressive and with no explanation. If Amazon is that concerned, require a signature. I'd rather pick it up at the post office the next day than to have a level of risk which clearly leans against the customer if delivery issues arise.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loses All Volume when powering back up after a powerfailure
reviews.reviewText: The Echo show (2nd Gen) loses all volume control when powering back up after a brief power failure/ or by unplugging the unit from the wall outlet for a few seconds. The only way to return volume function to the unit is to unplug the power from the back of the unit for 5 seconds....(unplugging from the wall outlet does not work). We often have power glitches in Florida and to come home and have the unit not have any volume is extremely annoying... the only way to return volume functionality is to unplug the unit from the back for 5 seconds. I thought I had a defective unit ... but the replacement unit is doing the exact same thing.... I invite all to try the experiment... unplug your unit from the wall for a few seconds and see what happens to your volume!

It's a vast improvement on the original Echo Show in aesthetics and audio quality, and it delivers most of what was missing from its predecessor for the same price. If you're decidedly on team Alexa, this smart display is the one for you. The second generation Echo Show is miles ahead of the original, but many of the first generation device's characteristics remain. Four microphones on the front of the device and four on the top only slightly change the look of the controls. As for better hearing, Alexa heard me the first time with the new Echo Show at distances where I had to repeat the wake word three or four times on the first generation unit, Also The redesign brought much-needed change which makes me a lot more likely to want an Echo Show on display in my own home. the second generation Echo Show sounds much fuller, deeper and just plain better than both its predecessor and the Lenovo Smart Display. That's true for video chatting, online content and music streaming. Yes, a Google Home or HomePod will still win out for room-filling, quality sound. But for a smart display the new Echo Show is no slouch. Speaking of Fire TV, the Echo Show will integrate with Fire TV Recast to put live TV on the Echo Show as a recording .Fire TV Recast is a DVR setup for your smart display. Not everyone will value watching real TV on a smart display, but if nothing else, Amazon is taking the logical step of marrying its video services to its video-capable hardware.

I've been using the Echo devices since their inception. I was fortunate enough to get into an early adoption queue.

It's amazing how embedded into my daily life these things have become. I use them for so many things - from morning repeating reminders to get my son his ADD medicine to timers for cooking and my favorite, adding things to my shopping list. I love being able to just ask for a song and have it play.

Weather forecasts, current temp outside, news synopsis... It has become such an integral part of our household.

The Echo Show was a nice addition, I liked the screen, especially when it came to monitoring multiple timers, or being able to look at lists without having to use the app. But it was a bit small for use across the room, so some things I didn't ask unless I was closer to it.

This new one removes that restriction. Screen is huge, seeing the two side by side is just amazing. It's bigger than I had expected just from reading the specs and measurements. Screen is vibrant and crisp, text is clear and photos are well displayed.

My son loves that there are so many genres of jokes he can ask.

I love that the Echo is one of the central parts of my automated home. Switches all over the house, lights, thermostat and video cameras - I love being able to just ask to see a camera and seeing it, or turning lights on and off, or changing the temperature of the house. I was happy before the Echo devices to be able to do all that from the cell phone, but it's even more useful now that the Echo can control so many things. Works well with IFTTT but I still prefer the skills where it can directly access something.

There just isn't a downside. I'm passing my V1 Echo Show to my mother, who also received my V1 Echo when I upgraded to the newer little cylinder tower for the V2 Echo. And I've given her my old V1 dot when I got the newer dot. It's nice having them in a few places around the house. The dot in my bedroom is my only alarm clock I use anymore, despite having a nice Philips glow light wakeup system... It is just so much easier to say, "Alexa, set alarm for 6 AM," than to hit the buttons on the alarm clock. Especially when you're setting different times for different days.

And even for napping sometimes - just tell it what time to sound the alarm, and take a little nap without worrying about napping too long and screwing up your sleep schedule.

Worth every penny for my household, wouldn't be without one anymore...

reviews.reviewTitle: No bad but it is missing some features.
reviews.reviewText: We recently received the Echo Show 2 as a gift. The sound quality is much better than the Echo Spots we have. Also being able to visually see multiple timers is very handy. Honestly I am extremely disappointed that I can not read my kindle cookbooks on the Echo Show. Sure you can have it read to you in Alexa's robotic voice but that isn't practical. I think not being able to access the kindle books is a huge flaw! If they would allow full access to your Kindle library that would make this product much more useful. Also would be handy to have icons for skills on a home screen because lets be honest some skills require very specific wording that doesn't roll of the tongue naturally. Overall it isn't terrible but it is missing some key features. If we had not received this as a gift we would not have purchased this unless they added those missing key features.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for news, music and organizing daily tasks
reviews.reviewText:
This is a great product. We’ve had it for three weeks. Our main takeaways:
- The power of this device is multiplied if you are already an Amazon prime/unlimited user. Even if you are not, I would seriously consider becoming one as a prime membership costs more or less the same than services that give you a similar access to media on other platforms, but also comes with free shipping for amazon items and other perks such as photo backups on amazon photo etc.
- This device is amazing for music if you have a compatible subscription. Keep in mind that amazon prime already gives you access to many songs. With this device, when I subscribed to amazon music unlimited, an add on, it cost me 3.99/month (although that only gives you access to this service in this device). It can also connect your cell phone to play music you might have downloaded there, and is compatible with Apple Music. Sound quality is leaps and bounds ahead of competitors.
- We also use it to get our daily news brief. You can select your sources and we play it as we are getting breakfast ready, very useful.
- Has some other interesting uses, like coordinating shopping lists between multiple users through apps, as well as reminders and alarms.
- Great for cooking as well with full integration with Allrecipes and other recipe skills.
- It has some quirky interesting games as well, but this is not a defining feature for me.
- One area where it lacks compared to some of the competition is trip/drive planning. I have deducted one star for this. There is no embedded map feature that I could find. Others have this. It will however tell you how long it will take you to get somewhere, but in my experience even this is a work in progress with times being shown differing from what my phone shows me.
- Outisde of news videos, have not had a chance to test the movie feature. I have not seen a Netflix skill, although I have read Hulu is supported (have never tested it myself).

All in all, don’t regret the purchase at all.

Right out of the box it had no audio, had it replaced and it worked. Ot sounded pretty good until it started acting buggy. Then no audio at all on anything. Now im waiting for a replacement. They made a ticket and still waiting. Apparently the factory that was making the units that I had gotten was shut down because all of the units from it were buggy. Im glad they hot shut down for it. I as well as others in my situation should not have to go through this. And wait impatiently for our replacement yet again. We should also get credits to our Amazon account for future purchases for all of this hassle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Still needs some work, but good
reviews.reviewText: I do love this item. We have had the Original Echo with Alexa for 5 years. I cannot be without Alexa!! We have always used as a timer, shopping list, Pandora, prime music, sleep sounds, and various other skills. I like the Show, but I had higher expectations. We are going to use it with the Ring Doorbell system and to video call relatives, but so far I have used it for recipes while cooking and prime video. So my problem is while using a recipe, I also wanted to set a timer. Once it goes to the timer, you can't tell her to resume the recipe, you have to ask her to find the recipe again and start over. I was also watching/listening to a movie and had the same issue. She won't just go back to where it left off. I had to ask for the movie again from scratch. But it did pick up where it left off once I got it back up. "Third world problems"! Overall, I'm glad I got it and cannot wait to find out what else it can do and see how it gets smarter over time, like the Echo.

It's about what I expected. It has a very clear display and once I found how to adjust the sound settings it actually sounds pretty good. It responds to my voice much as any of the echo devices. Showing the actual information that i request is a lot better than hearing it. Overall it seems to take the Alexa automation system to the next level.
I haven't found how to turn off the display yet. It does dim automatically after a while.
I bought it for $179 including a smart bulb from Best Buy.
I have the Alexa app installed on my phone and tablet. Both work seamlessly. I can control Alexa devices between different locations from either device. This feature gives me a great sense of security. Currently i have around 20 lights and switches connected. 3 different manufacturers of the devices. Plus 3 fire tv devices. All install and work easily.
Make sure your internet has a strong connection. Enjoy scheduled events and routines as well as manual control.
I love the drop in features so I have an intercom just in case my cellphone is outside of range.
I'm shopping for compatible affordable security cameras. When I find and install those the display will pay for itself.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound, useful for the home
reviews.reviewText:
The sound is very impressive, I was not expecting it to be as good as it is. We use it to listen to both Amazon Music and SiriusXM and it certainly doesn't disappoint even with the so-so quality of some of the Sirius channels.
We have several 'smart' plugs and switches in our home and this device makes it easy to control them all from one room using your voice or pulling up the list of devices on the screen and interacting with them that way. It is really helpful for managing a large number of connected devices.
I recently activated the 'intercom' feature for use with our old Echo 1st gen. I put the older Echo downstairs so that my spouse could communicate easily with me upstairs on the Echo Show if she wanted to (she just had a baby). This feature seems to be working well.
We also often use it for recipes, our Echo Show is on the kitchen counter. While the recipe displaying functions are great, the Alexa service is lacking in how it searches for recipes. Many times if will hear you correctly, but present you with a list of recipes that are nowhere near to what you asked for.
We have also used this device to quickly look up a product that we might quickly need for the baby or for mommy and it seems to do well in that regard, presenting you with relevant items.
Aside from that, it is also great at the general Alexa-type stuff; weather, sports scores, etc.
One kind of odd thing I noticed is that after enabling the 'messaging' (intercom) feature, skills I was using that had the word 'text' in their intent requests wouldn't work; the Alexa service would recognize the word 'text' and hijack the intent, ignoring the context of the rest of the user's input and instead asking you who you would like to text message. Not cool.

reviews.reviewTitle: Disappointed. Was hoping for more from a touch screen
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to use my show for streaming music mostly. But it isn't very helpful. you have to know exactly what you want to listen to there is no way to browse which is very disappointing as it has a screen. You're better off just getting an echo dot. The to do last and shopping list are huge pain to use. Almost everything wants to default to a shopping list which makes it next to impossible to make to do list and you can't change the default name on it.
